Reader boards, that is, any sign utilizing individually mounted and removable letters and numbers inserted into channels, except for price signs at fuel filling stations and reader boards which are part of approved signs at religious and institutional properties.
Detached and portable signs, whether or not trailer mounted.

Streamers, pennants and balloons hung from any building, structure pole or vehicle, placards attached or set in or upon vehicles for sale at any commercial property, and marking of windows of any vehicle for sale at any commercial property.
Any sign or banner erected in the public right-of-way or public easement except as provided in this article. Any signs or banners not specifically permitted under this article.
No windows maybe covered with paper or cloth except when the property is under construction and not opened to the public. Illegal signs in existence at the time of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be removed upon:
 
a.	Change of ownership of business.

b.	Change of use of building.

c.	Damage from any source, when the cost of repair exceeds 50 percent of the value of the original sign.

d.	Exterior renovation of said building.

(Code 1982, § 3-26; Ord. No. 4141, § VI, 5-10-1983; Ord. No. 4847, § 2, 10-13-1998; Ord. No. 5047, § XVIII, 3-26-2002; Ord. No. 5119, § I, 8-12-2003; Ord. No. 5154,
§ V, 1-27-2004; Ord. No. 5346, §§ III, IV, 6-13-2006)


Sec. 6-75. - Unsafe and unlawful signs.

The director of public works may cause to be removed any sign of immediate danger or hazard to persons or property without notice. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit to remain upon any premises owned, leased, occupied or used by him or it, with notice thereof, any unsafe or insecure  sign liable to injure any person or property or to maintain or permit to remain on any such premises any sign which, because of condition or appearance, would have a damaging effect upon other property in the city.

(Code 1982, § 3-27; Ord. No. 4141, § VII, 5-10-1983)


Sec. 6-76. - General requirements for all signs.

 
(a)
 
Construction. All signs shall be designed and constructed in conformity to the provisions and the requirements of this article, as set out hereafter:
 

(1)
 

Wind. The effect of special local wind pressures shall be thoroughly considered in the design; but the wind load shall not be assumed less
 

than 15 pounds per square foot for ground signs.
 

(2)


(3)


(4)



(5)



(6)
 

Illumination. A sign shall not be illuminated by other than electrical means and electrical devices and wiring shall be installed in accordance with the requirements of the National Electrical Code.
Obstructions to exit ways. A sign shall not be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, required exit way, window or door opening used as an element or a means of egress or access thereto, the firefighting forces having jurisdiction.
Obstruction to ventilation. A sign shall not be attached in any form, shape or manner which will interfere with any opening required for ventilation, except that such signs may be erected in front of and may cover transom windows when not in violation of the provisions of this Code.
Artistic quality. All signs shall be of a high artistic quality that will enhance its surroundings. Drawings of the proposed sign indicating colors and other specifications as required in this article (section 6 - 3 1 ) shall be submitted with the permit application. The design and review board shall review and approve the drawings of the permanent-type signs submitted with permit applications.
Use of combustibles.
 

a.	Ornamental features. Wood or approved plastic, or other material of combustible characteristics similar to wood, may be used for moldings, cappings, nailing blocks, letters and latticing and for other purely ornamental features of signs.
b.	Sign facings. Sign facings may be made of approved combustible plastics, provided the area of each face is not more than 100 square feet and the wiring for electric lighting is entirely enclosed in metal conduit and installed with a clearance of not less than two inches from the facing material.
 
(7)
 
Ground signs.
 

a.	Obstructions to traffic. A ground sign shall not be erected so as to obstruct free access to or egress from any building.

b.	Setback. A ground sign shall not be set nearer to the street lot line than one foot.

c.	Dimensions. No ground sign may exceed five feet in height and eight feet in length, including its foundation or planter box, with the actual sign area limited to 3 2 square feet per side.
d.	Construction. A ground sign shall not be constructed of combustible materials, except as provided herein.

e.	Landscaping. A ground sign shall have landscaping at the base of the sign.
 

(8)
 

Wall signs.
 

a.	Projection. A wall sign shall not project more than 15 inches from the wall of a building.

b.	Wall signs exceeding 40 square feet in area shall be constructed of noncombustible materials except as provided for herein.

c.	A wall sign shall not project beyond the top of the wall nor extend beyond the end of a wall to which it is attached, except the director of public works may allow a wall sign to be mounted on the roof of a building where the roof slopes upward from the front wall, provided the sign is parallel to and directly above the wall of the building facing the street.
 
(9)






(10)
 
Flags and flag poles. Flag poles and flags may be erected in the front yard of commercial, institutional or governmental buildings for the purpose of displaying the American flag, flags of any city, county, state or federal jurisdiction and flags with a specifically designed pattern or emblem of a firm or business located in the building on the site, provided no lettering or advertising is used. A maximum of two such flag poles and flags may be erected on any one building site and shall be uniform in height, size and arrangement according to acceptable standards for displaying flags.
Pole signs/post signs.
 

a.	In granting or denying approval of a permit for a pole sign pursuant to s e c t i o n 6 - 4 9 (b)(2), the city council shall determine whether the criteria listed below are true with respect to the proposed pole sign, and the applicant for such sign shall have an opportunity to be heard. The council shall approve the permit if it determines that all of the following criteria are true with respect to the proposed pole sign and shall deny the permit if it determines that any of such criteria are not true with respect to the proposed pole sign:
1.	Will not cause a traffic hazard;

2.	Will not diminish or impair property values within the neighborhood;

3.	Will not adversely affect the public health, safety, order, convenience or general welfare of the community;

4.	Is consistent with and not injurious to the character of the neighborhood; and

5.	Meets the requirements of subsection (a)(10)b of this section.

b.	All pole/post signs shall be subject to the following requirements:

1.	No more than one pole sign shall be allowed at each building, except as provided in subsection (a)(10)c of this section.

2.	Maximum height of a pole sign is 25 feet or the roofline, whichever is lower.

3.	No pole sign shall extend downward nearer than ten feet to the ground or pavement.

4.	The pole sign must be so located that no part of the sign may project beyond a one-foot setback line from any property line.

5.	The sign area of pole signs shall not exceed in square feet the number equaling one-half the linear foot frontage of property on which the pole sign is located less the sign area of any existing and proposed signs.
 

(b)
 

Maintenance and inspection.
 

(1)


(2)



(3)


(4)


(5)
 

Removal. The director of public works may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this article.
Maintenance. All signs, together with all their supports, braces, guys and anchors shall be kept in repair in accordance with the provisions of this article; and when not galvanized or constructed of approved corrosion-resistive, noncombustible materials shall be painted when necessary to prevent corrosion.
Housekeeping. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner or lessee of every sign to maintain the immediate premises occupied by the sign in a clean, sanitary and healthful condition.
Inspection. Every sign for which a permit has been issued shall be inspected upon erection to determine compliance with the provisions of this article.
Failure to notify for inspection. It shall be the duty of the permittee to notify the director of public works when the sign is erected and ready for inspection. Failure to notify the director of public works constitutes a violation of this section.
 
(Code 1982, § 3-28; Ord. No. 4141, § VIII, 5-10-1983; Ord. No. 4184, § 2, 6-12-1984; Ord. No. 4713, § 2, 1-9-1996; Ord. No. 4777, § 1, 5-13-1997; Ord. No. 4791, § 1,
7-22-1997; Ord. No. 5047, §§ XIX, XX, 3-26-2002; Ord. No. 5154, §§ VI—VIII, 1-27-2004; Ord. No. 5346, § V, 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 5709, § III, 8-13-2013)


Sec. 6-77. - Planned unit development (PUD) district signage.

 
(a)


(b)
 
In planned unit development (PUD) districts, the provisions of sections 6 - 2 9 , 6 - 3 1 , 6 - 4 9 (except for the provisions of sections 6 - 4 9 (c)), 6 - 7 3 , and 6 -

ARTICLE III. - EXTERIOR SIGNS IN PUD DISTRICTS



Sec. 6-100. - Intent and purpose.

 
(a)


(b)
 
The intent and purpose of this article is to provide a means for the execution of a coordinated exterior signage system designed to enhance the built environment and provide an overall, consistent design theme in keeping with the intent and purpose of a planned unit development (PUD).
Upon approval by the design and review board of an exterior signage plan as herein defined, the PUD developer may proceed with the erection of various signs within the development on an as-needed basis in accordance with the following guidelines:
 
(1)

(2)

(3)
 
No sign may be erected before obtaining a city permit;

The permit will be issued only to the authorized PUD developer;

The director of public works shall have the authority to grant permits for new signs without the necessity of design and review board approval as long as the proposed signs comply with the exterior signage plan approved by design and review board at the outset.
 
(Code 1982, § 3-51; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-101. - Defnitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Conditional approval means conditional approval is an action taken by the design and review board that state the board's general approval of the exterior signage plan but with conditions such as requests for additional information, clarifications and/or relatively minor modifications. The applicant may not initiate the proposed exterior signage plan under a conditional approval.

Developer means the owner of the property within a specified planned unit development (PUD) district and who is the applicant requesting review and approval of the specified exterior signage plan.

Development means the project developed by the applicant that has been approved by the city council to be constructed within the specified planned unit development (PUD) district.

Exterior signage plan (hereinafter referred to as the plan) means a plan which describes the objectives and performance standards for exterior signage within a specified planned unit development (PUD) district, the minimum requirements of such plan being further described herein. A plan shall be specifically identified as being a covenant unto an individually named development within a planned unit development (PUD) district.
 

Signs means any identification, description, illustration, directive, warning, instruction, illustration or other device displaying visual information, illuminated or nonilluminated, which is visible from any public place or is located on private property and exposed to the public and which directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business, solicitation or informative, directive, warning or instructive message, including any emblem, painting, symbol or placard intended to convey information for a limited period of time are not included under this article, but are included under the provisions of this article. Window displays and national flags are not included under the provisions of this article. For the purpose of removal, signs shall also include all sign structures.

Unconditional approval means the design and review board's approval of the applicant's exterior signage plan without any conditions. (Code 1982, § 3-52; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)

Sec. 6-102. - Permits.

 
(a)


(b)
 
Approval of the plan by the design and review board shall constitute an approval for the director of public works to grant permits to erect exterior signs allowed by the plan and conforming to the design standards established by the plan.
An existing sign shall not be altered in any way nor relocated unless such alteration or relocation is in conformance with the provisions for new signs as promulgated herein. Any such deviation from the approval exterior signage plan shall require re-review and approval by the design and review board.
 
(Code 1982, § 3-53; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-103. - Exterior signage plan.

 
(a)



(b)


(c)
 
Generally, an exterior signage plan shall describe the intended uses, locations, appearance, variety of sizes, materials and details of construction for all exterior signs. The plan shall be comprehensive in nature, serving as a detailed guide for all signage within a specified planned unit development (PUD) district.
The plan shall be identified as being the exterior signage plan for a specifically-named development and developer approved by the city and located within a planned unit development (PUD) district.
The plan shall include as a minimum, but is not limited to, the following information and submittal requirements:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)



(5)
 

The name and address of the developer submitting the plan.

The name and location of the development to which the plan pertains.

Verification that the developer has received city approval of its final development plan and all related subdivision plats.

Evidence of commitment to said plan by the developer by means of deed restrictions, private covenants, agreements or other formal commitments customarily used to control the use, development, construction and/or maintenance of all publicly and privately owned improvements within the development.
The types of signs, by function, that will be permitted and are anticipated to be erected, constructed or otherwise installed within the development. At a minimum, the type of functions shall include the following categories:
 
a.	Identification functions.

b.	Information functions.

c.	Vehicular control functions.
 

(6)

(7)
 

The types of signs that will not be permitted within the development.

Site plans which describe the anticipated locations of the various signs, by function and grouped as follows:
 

a.	Functions pertinent to major development entries and streets, shown on a drawing having a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet.
b.	Functions pertinent to individual buildings or building complex sites shown on a drawing having a scale of not less than one inch equals 40 feet.
 
(8)
 
Physical characteristics of the signage system, including:
 

a.	Variety of sizes and placements allowed in conjunction with the various functions.

b.	Types of materials to be utilized in the construction of the signs.

c.	Colors.

d.	Typeface style and size, including standard alphabet and numerals.

e.	Graphic composition.

f.	Method and type of illumination.

g.	Typical construction details.

h.	Symbols, logos and trademarks to be utilized.

i.	Architectural sketch, in color, depicting the appearance of each functional type of sign anticipated to be used.

j.	Dimensions for location of signs adjacent to street curbs, rights-of-way, building lines, setbacks and/or property lines.
 

 
(9)


(10)


(11)

(12)

(13)
 
Standards regarding placement, such as distance from a street curb, distance from an intersection and/or legibility (height and style of letters) related to vehicular speed and direction.
Guidelines regarding identification of owners, tenants or other building occupants including use of an owner's, tenant's or other occupant's logo, symbol or trademark.
Design and placement of vehicular traffic control signage, such as stop signs, speed limit signs, prohibited turns, prohibited access, etc. Design and placement of signage pertaining to physically disabled persons.
No sign will be erected that is deemed indecent or not in good taste.
 

(Code 1982, § 3-54; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-104. - Requirements for all signs.

 
(a)
 
Generally. All signs shall be designed, constructed or erected in conformity with the following requirements:
 

(1)


(2)


(3)


(4)


(5)


(6)



(7)



(8)
 

Wind. The effect of special local wind pressures shall be thoroughly considered in the design; but the wind load shall not be assumed less than 15 pounds per square foot.
Illumination. No sign shall be illuminated by other than electrical means and electrical devices and wiring shall be installed in accordance with the National Electrical Code, latest edition.
Obstruction to exit ways. No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, required exit way, window or door opening used as an element or a means of egress or access thereto, or the firefighting department having jurisdiction.
Traffic hazards. No sign may be located such that it substantially interferes with the view necessary for motorists to proceed safely through intersections or to enter onto or exit from public or private streets.
Interference with traffic signals. No sign shall be erected that due to its location, color, size, shape, nature or message would tend to obstruct the view of, or be confused with, traffic signals or other signs erected by governmental agencies.
Obstruction of ventilation. A sign shall not be attached in any form, shape or manner which will interfere with any opening required for ventilation, except that such signs may be erected in front of and may cover transom windows when not in violation of the provisions of this Code.
Use of combustibles. Sign facings may be fabricated of approved combustible plastics, provided the area of each face is not more than 100 square feet and the wiring for electric lighting is entirely enclosed in metal conduit and installed with a clearance of not less than two inches from the facing materials.
Flags and flag poles. Flag poles and flags may be erected in the front yard of commercial, institutional or governmental buildings for the purpose of displaying the American flag, flags of any city, county, state or federal jurisdiction. A maximum of two such flagpoles and flags may be erected on any one building site and shall be uniform in height, size and arrangement according to acceptable standards for displaying flags.
 
(b)
 
Right-of-way signage prohibited. No sign may be constructed on any public right-of-way.
 

(Code 1982, § 3-55; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-105. - Maintenance, inspection and removal.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)
 
Maintenance. All signs shall be of sound structural quality, be maintained in good repair and have a clean and neat appearance. Land adjacent to such signs shall be kept free from debris, weeds and trash.
Inspection. Every sign shall be inspected by the director of public works to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. Inspections shall be made in compliance with the provisions of the city's sign permit ordinance.
Removal. The director of public works may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this article or that is erected in violation of the provisions of this article.
 
(Code 1982, § 3-56; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-106. - General standards and criteria for approval.

The specified exterior signage plan shall only be approved after the design and review board makes specific findings of fact directly based on evidence presented by the developer supporting the following conclusions:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)
 

The specified exterior signage plan supports the intent and purpose of a planned unit development (PUD) district.

The proposed exterior signage plan supports and enhances the specified development in which the signage will be erected.

The proposed exterior signage plan meets the intent and spirit of this article and all other applicable city ordinances and codes. The proposed signage will be compatible with its surroundings, and appropriate to the uses for which it is intended.
 

(Code 1982, § 3-57; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)
 

Sec. 6-107. - Approval procedures.

The developer of a specified planned unit development shall submit an application to the director of public works for an exterior signage plan review and request for approval by the design and review board. Applications shall be processed according to the following criteria:
 

(1)


(2)
 

All applications shall be submitted in support of a planned unit development previously approved by the plan and zoning commission and the city council.
All applicants shall be required to submit a revised exterior signage plan if the initial plan is not approved or shall notify the director of public works that the applicant has chosen to rescind its application.
 

(Code 1982, § 3-58; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-108. - Application submittal for review and approval.

 
(a)
 
The proposed exterior signage plan complying with the requirements of this article and the requirements listed below shall accompany an application for review and approval. Applications to the design and review board for initial submittal review and approval shall be submitted to the director of public works at least 15 working days prior to the board meeting at which it is to be considered, together with:
 
(1)

(2)

(3)
 
Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. Name of the development.
15 copies of the exterior signage plan, the contents of such comply with the provisions of s e c t i o n 6 - 1 0 3 .
 

(b)



(c)
 

The director of public works shall forward a copy of the submittal to the zoning administrator for review and comment. The zoning administrator shall return his review comments to the director of public works not less than ten working days prior to the board meeting at which the plan is to be considered.
At the design and review board meeting at which the plan is to be considered, the plan and zoning commission shall review the application and take one of the following actions:
 
(1)

(2)


(3)
 
Unconditional approval of the exterior signage plan as submitted.

Conditional approval of the exterior signage plan subject to revisions of further information requested by either the board or the director of public works.
Rejection of the exterior signage plan, clearly stating the reasons for rejection.
 

(d)





(e)
 

Unconditional approval. If the design and review board gives an unconditional approval of the plan, the applicant can then initiate the plan without the requirement for permits or other applications, fees, etc.; except that if the applicant must modify the plan in some substantial manner, the applicant shall be required to notify the director of public works, requesting for a review and request for approval of all proposed modifications to the previously approved plan.
Conditional approval. If the design and review board gives a conditional approval of the plan:
 

(1)

(2)


(3)
 

The plan and zoning commission will clearly state its conditions.

The applicant shall reply to such conditions no later than ten working days prior to the next regularly scheduled board meeting. Such reply shall be in writing, accompanied by a modified plan, if required.
At its next regularly scheduled meeting, the board shall either:
 

a.	Give the modified plan its unconditional approval.

b.	Reject the application.
 

(4)
 

If the modified plan is rejected, the board shall clearly state its reasons and notify the applicant accordingly.
 

(f)
 

Rejection. If the board rejects the proposed exterior signage plan, the applicant may:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)
 

Appeal the decision to the city's board of adjustment. Modify the plan and reapply for review and approval.
Rescind the plan and proceed with signage under the provisions of article II of this chapter.
 

(Code 1982, § 3-59; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)


Sec. 6-109. - Time limit.

An unconditionally approved exterior signage plan shall be initiated within one year or it becomes null and void. (Code 1982, § 3-60; Ord. No. 4580, § 3, 2-9-1993)

Chapter 8 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL



Sec. 8-1. - Deinitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Hotel means every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for pay to transient or permanent guests, in which ten or more rooms are furnished for the accommodation of such guests, with or without meals.

Intoxicating liquor means alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt, or other liquors, or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous, or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of one-half of one percent by volume except for nonintoxicating beer as defined in RSMo 312.010.

Merchant means any person who deals in any goods of any kind, or owns or operates any place of business lawfully subject to regulation by the city.

Nonintoxicating beer means any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure abstract of hops, and pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals and wholesome yeast and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, and having an alcoholic content of more than 0.5 percent by volume, and not exceeding 3.2 percent by weight.

Original package means, as to intoxicating liquor, any container containing less than 187 milliliters; as to nonintoxicating beer, any package containing three, six, 12, or 24 small standard beer bottles, or such package containing such number of large standard beer bottles.

Premises means the entire building in which a licensee under the provisions of this chapter has his place of business, and any additional building used in connection with that building, the entire lot or lots, parcel or parcels of land on which those buildings are situated, or which are used in connection with that building.

Restaurant means every place in which the greater volume in value of business transacted in such place is in the sale of food for consumption in that place.

Transportation company means any person engaged in the business of transporting goods or merchandise for hire, by any means of conveyance.

Wholesale liquor dealing agent means any person who solicits, receives or takes orders for the purchase and delivery of intoxicating liquors to any person in the city.

(Code 1972, § 601.01; Code 1982, § 4-1; Ord. No. 4432, § I, 1-23-1990)


Sec. 8-2. - Nonapplication of chapter.

This chapter shall not apply to the possession by a druggist of intoxicating liquor purchased by him from a licensed vendor under RSMo ch. 311, or intoxicating liquor lawfully acquired and transported into the state by him pursuant to RSMo ch. 311, such liquor to be used in connection with the business of a druggist in compounding medicine or as a solvent or preservative, nor shall this chapter apply to the sale of intoxicating liquor by druggists on prescription from a regularly licensed physician.

(Code 1972, § 601.01A; Code 1982, § 4-2)


Sec. 8-3. - City oicials and employees not to have interest in establishment.

No member of the city council or any city employee shall have any interest of any kind, whether proprietary, as security for a loan or other lien for his benefit or in a fiduciary capacity or in any other capacity, in any premises where intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer is distilled, brewed, manufactured,
rectified, sold or offered for sale, or in any business in whole or in part which is devoted to the distilling, brewing, manufacturing, rectifying or sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, nor shall such person himself be involved directly or indirectly in such distilling, brewing, manufacturing, rectifying or sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, in any capacity whatever.

(Code 1972, § 601.04; Code 1982, § 4-7)


Sec. 8-4. - Drinking in assemblies.

 
(a)


(b)
 
No person shall enter any schoolhouse, church or courtroom in which there is an assemblage of people, met for a lawful purpose, and drink or offer to drink any intoxicating liquors in the presence of such assembly of people.
This section shall not apply to religious services in which drinking or offering to drink an intoxicating liquor is a part of such service.
 

(Code 1972, § 305.16; Code 1982, § 4-6; Ord. No. 3910, § 1, 10-24-1977)


Sec. 8-5. - Transportation companies to report shipments.
 

Every railroad, express, motor transportation or other transportation company, and every other person, who shall transport any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer into the city and deliver it to any person in the city shall, upon request, furnish the city council with a duplicate bill of lading or receipt for such intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, showing the name of the consignor and consignee, and the date, place and quantity received.

(Code 1972, § 601.14; Code 1982, § 4-8)


Sec. 8-6. - Enforcement; police.

The police of the city shall enforce the provisions of this chapter and shall report to the chief of police the name and address of the place at which a violation occurs, and the name and address of the proprietor or manager of any place which is not kept in an orderly manner, or which otherwise violates the provisions of this chapter.

(Code 1972, § 601.18; Code 1982, § 4-10)


Secs. 8-7—8-30. - Reserved.


ARTICLE II. - LICENSING AND REGULATION


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY



Sec. 8-31. - Qualiications and conditions of licensure.

 
(a)










(b)
 
No person shall be granted a license under the provisions of this chapter unless such person is of good moral character, or, in the case of a corporation, whose managing officer is of good moral character; nor shall a license be granted or retained if such person or managing officer has ever had a permit or license revoked under the liquor laws of any state, or who has been convicted since ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States of any violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, or who employs in his business any person whose permit or license has been revoked under the  liquor laws of any state, or who has been convicted of violating any provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, since the ratification of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. In addition, no person shall be granted a license to sell nonintoxicating beer unless such person is a taxpaying citizen and a qualified legal voter of the city.
No license shall be granted or retained under the provisions of this chapter for the sale of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises if:
 
(1)

(2)


(3)
 
The premises includes a building occupied or used for immoral or unlawful purpose;

The premises or room or portion of a building is connected by an entrance or exit or other means of communication with any room or place used for an immoral or unlawful purpose;
The place where intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer is sold at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises:
 

a.	Has any gambling device on the premises;

b.	Has any tables concealed or enclosed in private rooms or by partition or rooms;
 

(4)
 

In the case of the sale of intoxicating liquor at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises, the place where such intoxicating liquor is sold:
 
a.	Is in any drugstore, cigar and tobacco store, grocery store or confectionery or delicatessen store;

b.	Is within 100 feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, unless the applicant for the license shall first obtain the consent in writing of the board of directors of the school, or the consent in writing of the majority of the managing board of the church or place of worship; except that when a school, church or place of worship shall hereafter be established within 100 feet of any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, the license shall not be denied for lack of consent in writing as herein provided.
 
(c)
 
No license shall be issued for the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package, not to be consumed on the premises where sold, except to a person engaged in, and to be used in connection with the operation of one or more of the following businesses: a drugstore, a cigar and tobacco store, a grocery store, a general merchandise store, a confectionery or a delicatessen store, nor to any such person who does not have and keep in his store a stock of goods having a value according to invoices of at least $1,000.00, exclusive of fixtures and intoxicating liquors.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.06(A), (C), (D); Code 1982, § 4-49; Ord. No. 3911, § 1, 10-24-1977; Ord. No. 4032, § 1, 3-11-1980; Ord. No. 5011, § I, 8-28-2001)


Sec. 8-32. - Prohibition of sale at certain times.

 
(a)
 
No person having a license under the provisions of this chapter shall sell, give or otherwise dispose of, or allow to be sold, given or otherwise disposed of, any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer:
 

(1)

(2)
 

Between 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any weekday;

In the case of nonintoxicating liquor, between 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday; in the case of nonintoxicating beer, between 6:00
a.m.	and 1:00 p.m. on Sunday.
 

(b)


(c)
 

Every person who has obtained a license under the provisions of this chapter to sell at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises shall keep all doors locked and allow no patrons on the premises during the times on the days as stated in subsection (a) of this section.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section:
 

(1)






(2)


(3)
 

When January 1, March 17, July 4, or December 31 falls on Sunday, and on the Sundays prior to Memorial Day and Labor Day and on the Sunday on which the national championship game of the national football league is played, commonly known as "Super Bowl Sunday," any person having a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink may be open for business and sell intoxicating liquor by the drink under the provisions of his license on that day from the time and until the time which would be lawful on another day of the week, notwithstanding any provisions of this section to the contrary.
Where the licensee is authorized to sell by the drink as a club or hotel, this section shall apply only to those rooms in which such intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer is sold or otherwise dispensed.
Where a license to sell intoxicating liquor is held by a restaurant whose business is conducted in one room only and substantial quantities of food and merchandise other than intoxicating liquors are dispensed, the licensee shall keep securely locked, during the hours and on the days specified in subsection (a) of this section, all refrigerators, cabinets, cases, boxes and taps from which intoxicating liquor is dispensed.
 
(d)
 
Notwithstanding subsection (a)(2) of this section, every person with a Sunday sales license obtained pursuant to s e c t i o n 8 - 1 8 9 (b)(3)g shall be allowed to operate from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Sundays, subject to any state law requirements regarding operating times, and every person with a Sunday sales license obtained pursuant to s e c t i o n 8 - 1 8 9 (b)(3)i shall be allowed to operate from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Sundays.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.11; Code 1982, § 4-30; Ord. No. 3824, § 1, 7-14-1975; Ord. No. 4096, § 1, 6-23-1981; Ord. No. 4185, § 1, 6-26-1984; Ord. No. 4339, § 1, 1-26-
1988; Ord. No. 4455, § I, 6-12-1990; Ord. No. 4612, §§ 1, 2, 7-13-1993; Ord. No. 4673, § 1, 1-10-1995; Ord. No. 5130, § I, 10-14-2003)


Sec. 8-33. - Vacating premises during closed hours.

 
(a)






(b)
 
No person having a license under the provisions of this chapter, his agents or employees shall permit or allow any person to be inside the liquor licensed premises or on any patio or garden under the control of the liquor licensee during the hours when the sale of intoxicating liquor and nonintoxicating beer on said premises is prohibited, except that employees and contractors of the liquor licensee, and entertainers who have been performing at said premises may remain thereon, solely for the purpose of cleaning, restocking, loading and unloading equipment and supplies, performing maintenance work, and other business purposes.
No person shall enter or remain inside a liquor licensed premises or on any patio or garden under the control of the license licensee during the hours when the sale of intoxicating liquor and nonintoxicating beer on said premises is prohibited, except that employees and contractors of the liquor licensee, and entertainers who have been performing at said premises may remain thereon, solely for the purpose of cleaning, restocking, loading and unloading equipment and supplies, performing maintenance work, and other business purposes.
 
(Ord. No. 5449, § I, 1-22-2008)


Sec. 8-34. - Application for license.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)
 
No license shall be issued under the provisions of this chapter unless it has been approved by the city council at a regular or special meeting of the council, evidenced by a certificate over the signature of the mayor.
The applicant shall file with the city council a petition for a license that is signed and sworn to by the applicant, setting out his compliance with the conditions to the granting of such a license as set forth in this chapter.
In the case of an application for a license to sell intoxicating liquor at retail, the applicant shall also state:
 

(1)








(2)



(3)
 

If an individual, his full name, age, residence, place of birth, and if naturalized, the place and date of naturalization; whether or not he has been convicted of a felony or the violation of any law regulating or prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquor since the adoption of the Twenty-First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States; whether, when and where he has been engaged in the manufacture or sale or distribution of intoxicating liquor, and the nature of the business; and whether and to what extent any distiller, wholesaler, winemaker, brewer or an employee, agent, officer, affiliate or subsidiary thereof has an interest of any kind or proposes to have an interest of any kind in the applicant's retail business for which a license is sought, or has made any gift or loan of money, credit or equipment, or will make such loan or gift outside the ordinary commercial credit or sales made to the applicant.
If a corporation, the same information as in the case of individuals concerning the managing officer of each place of business, and, in addition, the names and addresses of its officers, directors and all persons directly or indirectly financially interested in the proposed business, the state of incorporation, the amount of capital stock, and its full corporate name.
In all cases, the exact location of the proposed place or premises where the applicant proposes to engage in the retail liquor business, fully describing such premises and setting forth all entrances and exits, the doors and windows, and the visibility of the interior from any street or sidewalk or other place on the outside of the premises, and the plans and specifications of proposed fixtures and equipment to be used.
 

 
(4)
 
In all cases, the nature of business conducted in other parts of the building or premises in or on which the applicant's business is to be located, the kind of business the applicant intends to conduct in the premises and the hours during which the business is to remain open.
 
(d)
 
The application for a license either to sell intoxicating liquor at retail, or to provide live entertainment in establishments having a license to sell any intoxicating beverages at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises, shall require a public hearing before the city council with notices being sent 15 days before the public hearing to all property owners within 200 feet from the proposed location in all directions.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.08; Code 1982, § 4-51; Ord. No. 3921, § 1, 1-9-1978; Ord. No. 5030, § I, 11-27-2001)


Sec. 8-35. - Licensees to fle periodic statements.

Every licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall file, on or before the fifth day of each calendar month, in the office of the city clerk, a sworn statement showing the amount of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer manufactured or sold, and to whom sold during the preceding calendar month.

(Code 1972, § 601.15; Code 1982, § 4-9)


Sec. 8-36. - Restriction on interest in and obligations of licensees' business.

 
(a)







(b)
 
Brewers or manufacturers of nonintoxicating beer, or the employees, officers or agents thereof, or their subsidiaries or affiliates, shall not, under any circumstances or in any way, obtain any financial interest in the retail business for the sale of nonintoxicating beer licensed under the provisions of this chapter, nor shall they in any way give or furnish equipment, money or credit other than commercial credit for nonintoxicating beer sold, to such licensee. No licensee shall enter into any contract or other agreement with any brewer or manufacturer of nonintoxicating beer, or their officers, employees or agents, or their subsidiaries or affiliates, obligating the licensee to buy or sell only that person's product, or to buy or sell the major part of that licensee's requirements from such person. Any such contract or agreement shall be void.
Manufacturers, rectifiers, distillers, wholesalers, winemakers, brewers or their employees, officers or agents, affiliates or subsidiaries shall not, under any circumstances or in any way, obtain any financial interest in the retail business for the sale of intoxicating liquor licensed under the provisions of this chapter, nor shall they in any way give or furnish equipment, money or credit other than commercial credit for intoxicating liquor sold, to such licensee. No licensee shall enter into any contract or other agreement with any manufacturer, rectifier, distiller, wholesaler, winemaker or brewer, its officers, employees or agents, or its affiliates or subsidiaries, obligating the licensee to buy or sell only that person's product, or to buy or sell the major part of that licensee's requirements from such person. Any such contract or agreement shall be void.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.07; Code 1982, § 4-50)


Sec. 8-37. - Display required.

All licensees under the provisions of this chapter shall keep their licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter in a conspicuous place in the place for which such license was issued.

(Code 1972, § 601.12; Code 1982, § 4-55; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Sec. 8-38. - Revocation; suspension.

 
(a)



(b)





(c)



(d)


(e)
 
Whenever it is shown that a person licensed under the provisions of this chapter has kept a disorderly place or house, or has violated the provisions of this chapter, or of any lawful order issued thereunder, in any way, the city council, in its discretion, may revoke or suspend the license of such person.
Suspension shall be for no longer than ten days. Where a license is revoked, the person whose license is revoked may not obtain another license under the provisions of this chapter, for any premises, for a period of two years from the date of revocation. Refusal to reissue a license shall not be deemed a revocation for this purpose unless such refusal to reissue follows the required procedures as set forth in this section, and the city council is explicit in making the refusal to reissue tantamount to such revocation.
Before a license may be revoked or suspended, the city council shall notify the licensee in writing of the time, date and place of the meeting, and of the charge or complaint upon which the suspension or revocation is to be based. Such notice shall issue no later than ten days after the issuance of the charge or complaint, and the date and time of the hearing shall be within a reasonable time after notice is sent.
For purposes of this section, notice will be deemed sufficient if it is served in a manner that conforms to the standards set forth by the laws of the state for service of process.
The city council shall exercise its discretion to suspend and revoke in a reasonable manner, and only if the charge or complaint referred to in the notice is found to be true and sufficient grounds for such revocation or suspension are found.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.19; Code 1982, § 4-56; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Sec. 8-39. - Report of revocations.
 

The city council shall report promptly to the state supervisor of liquor control all cases in which licenses issued pursuant to this chapter relating to intoxicating liquors have been revoked, and all cases in which persons licensed to sell nonintoxicating beer have been found to be selling intoxicating liquor in the city.

(Code 1972, § 601.3A; Code 1982, § 4-57; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Sec. 8-40. - Renewal.

 
(a)


(b)
 
Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be renewed upon its expiration upon the payment of the annual fee then prescribed by ordinance, provided the city council is satisfied that the conditions under which the license was granted still remain.
Renewal license applications not received by the specified time will be required to pay an additional $25.00 as and for a late fee and is not to be included in the regular license fee.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.10; Code 1982, § 4-58; Ord. No. 4006, § 1, 10-9-1979; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Sec. 8-41. - Certain acts prohibited in premises licensed to sell at retail intoxicating liquor, wine or beer.

 
(a)
 
It shall be unlawful for any retail licensee, licensed to sell intoxicating liquor, wine or beer, or his/her employee to permit in, upon or about the licensed premises:
 
(1)


(2)


(3)

(4)


(5)


(6)
 
The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law;
The displaying of any portion of the areola of the female breast or failure to cover the entire breast below the highest point of the areola with opaque fabric covering;
The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals;

The actual or simulated displaying of the pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals or failure to cover pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals with opaque fabric covering;
Any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes to public view any portion of his/her genitals or anus or fails at any time to have and keep opaque fabric covering over all parts of his/her genitals and anus; and
The displaying of films, video or DVD programs or pictures depicting acts, the live performances of which are prohibited by this regulation or by any other law.
 
(b)

(c)
 
Body paint, body dyes, tattoos, liquid latex, whether wet or dried, and other similar substances shall not be considered an opaque fabric covering. In addition to the licensee and/or his/her employee being subject to all penalties contained in this Code, violation of any act or any provision
contained herein shall be grounds for the license of the licensee to be suspended or revoked.
 

(Ord. No. 5816, § 3, 5-24-2016)


Secs. 8-42—8-68. - Reserved.


DIVISION 2. - INTOXICATING LIQUOR



Sec. 8-69. - Number of intoxicating liquor licenses limited.

 
(a)
 
No more than one license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold in the city shall be granted for every 200 inhabitants of the city or any fractional part thereof. No more than 40 percent of the above described licenses shall be issued to establishments which do not meet the following criteria:
 
(1)

(2)

(3)
 
Is licensed as a restaurant;

Derives over 50 percent of their income from the sale of food;

Has dining room seating exclusive of any separate bar area seating for 40 or more patrons.
 

(b)
 

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, licenses to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold in the city may be granted to not-for-profit corporate private clubs in a number not to exceed one license for every 5,000 inhabitants of the city or any fractional part thereof.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.05; Code 1982, § 4-48; Ord. No. 4658, § 1, 8-9-1994; Ord. No. 5309, § I, 1-10-2006; Ord. No. 5518, § I, 5-12-2009; Ord. No. 5710, § I, 8-13-2013;
Ord. No. 5881, § I, 3-27-2018)


Sec. 8-70. - License for retail sale of intoxicating liquor; hearing; approval.

 
(a)
 
Upon the filing of a petition for the granting of a license for the sale at retail of intoxicating liquor, the city council shall fix a date for a hearing
 

within ten days after the filing of such petition. The applicant shall have written notice of the date and time of the hearing.
 

(b)





(c)
 

At the hearing, the applicant may be represented by counsel and may call witnesses. The city council may itself subpoena witnesses, take testimony under oath, and the city council shall hear any assessed taxpaying citizen who occupies or conducts business in any building within 200 feet of the place in which the proposed retail liquor business is to be conducted, and such citizens may themselves produce witnesses and testimony.
If the city council finds that the applicable provisions of law, both in this chapter and in the Revised Statutes of Missouri, are met, and that the applicant will conduct his business in accordance with the applicable provisions of law, and if the city council further finds that the application is in fact supported by a majority of the assessed taxpaying citizens occupying or conducting businesses in buildings within 200 feet of the place where the proposed retail liquor business is to be conducted, the council shall approve the application.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.08A; Code 1982, § 4-52)


Sec. 8-71. - Sale of intoxicating liquors restricted.

 
(a)



(b)


(c)
 
No person holding a license to manufacture intoxicating liquors shall sell such liquors at wholesale or retail, or deliver such liquor except in a container having painted or printed in bold and legible letters the name of the manufacturer and the percentage of alcoholic content by weight of such liquor.
No person holding a license to manufacture or sell intoxicating liquors or to sell intoxicating liquors at wholesale in the city, shall ship liquors out of the state or outside the city limits for the purpose of evading or as part of a plan to evade any of the requirements of this chapter.
No person holding a license to sell intoxicating liquors at retail in the original package, not to be consumed on the premises where sold, shall sell such intoxicating liquor in an original package containing less than eight ounces.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.03; Code 1982, § 4-29)


Sec. 8-72. - Certain displays prohibited.

No intoxicating liquor, or package, bottle or container showing the label or brand of any intoxicating liquor, shall be displayed in any street window or show window.

(Code 1972, § 601.17; Code 1982, § 4-32)


Sec. 8-73. - Special regulations concerning sale of beer in chilled glass containers.

No person holding a license to sell intoxicating liquors at retail in the original package, not to be consumed on the premises where sold, or a license to sell nonintoxicating beer in the original package shall sell beer in glass containers of 32 ounces or greater that are chilled or refrigerated to a temperature that is below room temperature of the licensed premises.

(Code 1982, § 4-33; Ord. No. 4659, § 1, 8-9-1994)


Sec. 8-74. - Restrictions on sale of intoxicating liquor.

 
(a)


(b)
 
No person shall manufacture, distill, offer or expose for sale, sell or give away in this city any intoxicating liquor that has not obtained and does not possess a valid license as provided by this chapter.
No person shall sell or deliver intoxicating liquor for resale to any person not licensed under the provisions of this chapter.
 

(Code 1972, § 601.03(B)(1), (2); Code 1982, § 4-47)


Secs. 8-75—8-91. - Reserved.


DIVISION 3. - NONINTOXICATING BEER



Sec. 8-92. - License required.

No person shall manufacture, brew or sell at wholesale or at retail, any nonintoxicating beer in the city, or shall any person own, manage, operate or control any beer depot or storage room handling, storing or selling nonintoxicating beer in the city, unless he has acquired a license under the provisions of this  chapter, and such license is then valid.

(Code 1972, § 601.03(A)(2); Code 1982, § 4-46)


Sec. 8-93. - Containers of nonintoxicating beer to be labeled; sale restricted.

 
(a)
 
Every manufacturer or brewer of nonintoxicating beer who sells or ships for sale in the city any nonintoxicating beer, at wholesale or at retail,
 

shall cause every bottle, barrel, keg or other container of such beer to be marked with a label stating in plain letters and figures "Alcoholic content not in excess of 3.2 percent by weight" or "Alcoholic content not in excess of four percent by volume."
 
(b)


(c)
 
Any container not so labeled or marked as set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be deemed to contain intoxicating liquor and the sale thereof shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter regulating the sale of intoxicating liquor.
No person shall sell or offer for sale in the city any nonintoxicating beer unless it is:
 

(1)


(2)
 

Sold in the original bottle or in the original package containing bottles bearing the original label and full name of the brewer or manufacturer upon both the label and the bottle, and upon the cap or cork of such bottle; or
Sold on draft drawn from the original keg or barrel having stamped on the ends thereof the full name of the manufacturer or brewer of the beer contained therein.
 
(Code 1972, §§ 601.03(A)(1), 601.13; Code 1982, § 4-28)


Sec. 8-94. - Intoxicating liquor prohibited on nonintoxicating beer license premises.

No person holding a license to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail shall allow on or about the premises covered by the license any intoxicating liquor of any kind or character, nor shall any person sell for resale or use on the premises any intoxicating liquor to a person holding a license to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail.

(Code 1972, § 601.03(A)(3); Code 1982, § 4-4)


Sec. 8-95. - Possession of nonintoxicating beer restricted.

No person shall possess any nonintoxicating beer within the city which has not been acquired from a person licensed to sell or otherwise supply such beer to him, and if the package in which the beer is contained and from which it is taken for consumption has not been labeled and sealed as provided by this chapter add by lawful regulations issued under the, authority of this Code.

(Code 1972, § 601.03(A)(4); Code 1982, § 4-5)


Secs. 8-96—8-118. - Reserved.


DIVISION 4. - WINE AND BRANDY



Sec. 8-119. - Wine or brandy manufacturing; what sales may be made, when.

 
(a)





(b)







(c)






(d)
 
For the privilege of manufacturing wine or brandy, which manufacturing shall be in accordance with all provisions of federal law applicable thereto except as otherwise may be specified in this section, in quantities not to exceed 500,000 gallons, not in excess of 18 percent of alcohol by weight for wine, or not in excess of 34 percent of alcohol by weight for brandy, there shall be paid and collected, in lieu of the charges provided in
 s e c t i o n 8 - 1 8 9 , a license fee of $300.00, but in no event shall the license fee imposed hereby exceed the amount paid pursuant to RSMo 311.190. Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, a manufacturer licensed under this section may purchase and sell bulk or packaged
wines or brandies received from other licensed manufacturers and may also purchase in bulk, bottle and sell to duly licensed wineries,
wholesalers and retail dealers on any day except Sunday, and a manufacturer licensed under this section may offer samples of wine, may sell wine and brandy in its original package directly to consumers at the winery, and may open wine so purchased by customers so that it may be consumed on the winery premises on Monday through Saturday between 6:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight and on Sunday between 11:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary and provided that all requirements under applicable state statutes and regulations have been satisfied, the city may issue a license to a wine manufacturer, its employees, officers or agents to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises where sold, if the premises so licensed is in close proximity to the winery. Such premises may remain open between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday, and between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., Sunday.
Except as specifically provided in this section, in all respects the provisions of this chapter shall apply to applicants and licensees for the privilege of manufacturing wine or brandy.
 
(Code 1982, § 4-59; Ord. No. 5011, § II, 8-28-2001; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Secs. 8-120—8-136. - Reserved.


DIVISION 5. - MICROBREWERIES
 

Sec. 8-137. - Microbrewery deined; license fee; retail license allowed, procedure; sale to wholesalers allowed, when.

 
(a)


(b)



(c)



(d)



(e)
 
As used in this section, the term "microbrewery" means a business whose primary activity is the brewing and selling of beer, with an annual production of 10,000 barrels or less.
A microbrewer's license shall authorize the licensee to manufacture beer and malt liquor in quantities not to exceed 10,000 barrels per annum. In lieu of the charges provided in s e c t i o n 8 - 1 8 9 , there shall be paid and collected a license fee of $250.00, but in no event shall the license fee imposed hereby exceed the amount paid pursuant to RSMo 311.195.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary, the holder of a microbrewer's license may apply for, and the supervisor of liquor control may issue, a license to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink at retail for consumption on the brewery premises and in the original package for off-premises consumption.
The holder of a microbrewer's license may also sell beer and malt liquor produced on the brewery premises to duly licensed wholesalers. However, holders of a microbrewer's license shall not, under any circumstances, directly or indirectly, have any financial interest in any wholesaler's business, and all such sales to wholesalers shall be subject to the restrictions of RSMo 311.181 and 311.182.
Except as specifically provided in this section, in all respects the provisions of this chapter shall apply to all microbrewery applicants and licensees.
 
(Code 1982, § 4-60; Ord. No. 5011, § II, 8-28-2001; Ord. No. 5401, § II, 5-8-2007)


Secs. 8-138—8-157. - Reserved.


DIVISION 6. - MINORS



Sec. 8-158. - Purchases, possession by minors.

No person below the age of 21 years shall purchase, attempt to purchase or have in his possession or under his control any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer.

(Code 1972, § 601.02A(D); Code 1982, § 4-3; Ord. No. 3729, § 1, 5-30-1973)


Sec. 8-159. - Selling or supplying restriction to minors; violation.

 
(a)






(b)
 
No person shall sell or supply intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer, or permit the same to be sold or supplied, to any person who is under  or apparently under the influence of alcohol, or to an habitual drunkard. Intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer shall not be given, sold or otherwise supplied to any person under the age of 21 years, except that this shall not apply to the supplying of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to a person under such age for medicinal purposes only, or, in the case of nonintoxicating beer, by the parent or guardian of such person, or to the administering of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to such person by a physician.
In addition to any other penalties imposed by this Code, violation of this section shall subject the violator to the loss of his license to conduct business in the city.
 
(Code 1972, § 601.02; Code 1982, § 4-26)


Sec. 8-160. - Sale by persons under 21 years of age prohibited.

No person under the age of 21 years shall sell or assist in the sale or dispensing of intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer except where such person is permitted to do so under the laws of this state.

(Code 1972, § 601.02A(A), (C); Code 1982, § 4-27)


Secs. 8-161—8-188. - Reserved.


ARTICLE III. - FEES



Sec. 8-189. - License issuance, fees; collection.

 
(a)
 
Licenses issued under this chapter are nontransferable and are valid for one year, from July 1 to June 30. Licenses may be issued for less than one year, with the proportionate reduction in license fees, as follows:
 
(1)

(2)
 
To applicants whose licenses commence after January 1: one-half year; To applicants whose licenses commence after April 1: one-quarter year.
 
(b)
 
Subject to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, licenses shall be issued by the city clerk upon the following conditions and the payment
 

of the following fees:
 

(1)

(2)
 

A license shall cover a single premises only, and shall particularly describe such premises. Nonintoxicating beer license fees shall be as follows:
 
a.	To manufacture or brew nonintoxicating beer, which shall be construed to authorize the sale of such beer to distributors and wholesalers for resale to retailers only, or to retailers directly, but not to consumers: $375.00.
b.	To sell as distributor or wholesaler, which shall be construed to authorize the sale of such beer only to persons authorized to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail, but shall not authorize the licensee to sell to consumers: $75.00.
c.	To sell nonintoxicating beer at retail not for consumption on the premises, in the original package, which shall not authorize the licensee to sell such beer for consumption on the premises where sold: $22.50.
d.	To sell nonintoxicating beer at retail for consumption on the premises, which shall be construed to authorize the sale of such nonintoxicating beer by the glass, by the bottle, on draught, or in the original package: $37.50.
e.	For a beer depot or store room handling, selling or storing nonintoxicating beer: $75.00.
 

(3)
 

Intoxicating liquor license fees shall be as follows:
 

a.	For the privilege of manufacturing, distilling, blending and/or brewing in this city:

1.	Malt liquor containing not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight and the privilege of selling to duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale of malt liquors containing not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight, to, by or through duly licensed wholesaler: the sum of $250.00.
2.	Intoxicating liquor containing not in excess of 22 percent of alcohol by weight and the privilege of selling to duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale of intoxicating liquor containing not in excess of 22 percent of alcohol by weight, to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler: the sum of $200.00.
3.	Intoxicating liquor of all kinds within this city and the privilege of selling duly licensed wholesalers and soliciting orders for the sale of intoxicating liquor of all kinds, to, by or through a duly licensed wholesaler: the sum of $450.00.
b.	To sell intoxicating liquor at wholesale, which shall be subject to the same conditions regarding the sale of such intoxicating liquor as are licenses to manufacture, rectify, distill and blend; for handling:
1.	Intoxicating liquor containing not more than five percent of alcohol by weight: $75.00.

2.	Intoxicating liquor containing not more than 22 percent alcohol by weight: $150.00.

3.	Intoxicating liquors of all kinds: $375.00.

c.	To sell intoxicating liquor in excess of five percent by weight by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises: $450.00.

d.	To sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail only, and not by the drink for consumption on the premises, which shall include the right to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail in the original package: $150.00.
e.	To sell malt liquor containing alcohol over 3.2 percent but not more than five percent by weight at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises, which shall include the right to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises:
$52.50.

f.	To sell malt liquor, as described in subsection (b)(3)e of this section, at retail in the original package to consumers, but not by the drink for consumption on the premises, which shall include the right to sell nonintoxicating beer direct to consumers in the original package, but not by the drink for consumption on the premises: $22.50.
g.	To sell intoxicating liquor in excess of five percent by weight by the drink at retail for consumption on the premises (which shall include the right to nonintoxicating beer at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises) on Sundays between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight provided all requirements of state law are complied with: $300.00.
h.	To provide live entertainment in establishments having a license as described in subsections (b)(3)c, (b)(3)e and (b)(3)g of this section:
$125.00.

i.	To sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail only, and not by the drink for consumption on the premises (which shall include the right to sell nonintoxicating beer at retail in the original package) on Sundays between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight: $300.00.
j.	Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter to the contrary, any person possessing the qualifications in meeting the requirements of this chapter whose is licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail may apply for a special permit to conduct wine, malt beverage and distilled spirit tasting on the licensed premises. A licensee under this section shall pay $25.00 per year payable at the same time and manner as the packaged liquor fee. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to permit the licensee to sell wine, malt beverages or distilled spirits for on-premises consumption.
 
(4)


(5)
 
The payment of any license fee under the provisions of this chapter shall not relieve the licensee from liability for merchants' license or ad valorem taxes assessed and levied under other provisions of this Code and other ordinances.
Intoxicating liquor shall not be consumed on the premises of a person licensed under subsection (b)(3)d or (b)(3)f of this section except as otherwise provided in this chapter.
 

(6)


(7)
 

No licensee shall keep or secret or allow anyone else to keep or secret on the premises described in the license any intoxicating liquor other th character and kind expressly authorized to be sold by such license.
All fees collected pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be accounted for and paid into the city treasury.
 

(Code 1972, § 601.09; Code 1982, § 4-53; Ord. No. 3823, § 1, 7-14-1975; Ord. No. 3912, § 1, 11-14-1977; Ord. No. 4185, § 2, 6-26-1984; Ord. No. 4432, § II, 1-23-
1990; Ord. No. 4612, §§ 3, 4, 7-13-1993; Ord. No. 4673, § 2, 1-10-1995; Ord. No. 5041, § I, 2-26-2002; Ord. No. 5555, § I, 1-12-2010)


Sec. 8-190. - Advertising fees.

All applicants for liquor licenses that require a public hearing must pay the cost to advertise for the public hearing. This is a nonrefundable fee that offsets the cost of advertising.

(Code 1982, § 4-54; Ord. No. 5401, § I, 5-8-2007)


Chapter 10 - ANIMALS AND FOWL


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL



Sec. 10-1. - Dead animals.

No person shall permit any animal owned by him after it is dead to remain unburied for over 12 hours after it is dead. (Code 1982, § 6-1; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)

Sec. 10-2. - Raising certain animals prohibited.

No person shall raise or keep in the city any livestock such as horses, cattle, pigs, sheep, goats or any other useful animals traditionally kept or raised on a farm or ranch, including miniature versions of the aforementioned animals. No person shall raise in the city any pigeons, poultry (except as allowed in s e c t i o n 
 1 0 - 3 ), rabbits or other rodents unless raised or kept within biological laboratories, hospitals or pet shops.

(Code 1982, § 6-2; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 5525, § I(6-2), 6-9-2009; Ord. No. 5844, § I, 10-10-2017)


Sec. 10-3. - Poultry.

 
(a)
 
The keeping of up to six chickens or ducks in total shall be permitted as provided in this section only in the SR single-family residential zoning district and only if a permit has been issued by the director of public works. A permit to keep not more than six chickens or ducks in total on any parcel of property located within a SR single-family residential zoning district shall be issued by the director of public works if the following conditions are satisfied:
 
(1)


(2)

(3)


(4)

(5)

(6)
 
The chickens or ducks must be adequately confined within a yard or other place surrounded by wire netting or other fence as a provision to prevent their escape therefrom.
The pen shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition.

Any manure or other discharges from the chickens or ducks shall be collected and properly removed from the premises or tilled into the soil on the premises promptly and regularly to prevent the spreading of offensive smells or diseases.
The keeping of roosters shall be strictly prohibited.

No slaughtering of any chickens or ducks kept pursuant to a permit issued under this section shall be allowed. No person shall keep chickens or ducks in any manner as to create a nuisance under c h a p t e r 3 4 , article VIII.
 
(b)
 
The keeping of chickens or ducks pursuant to a permit issued under this section shall comply with all ordinances of the city. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to preclude the enforcement of any violation of any city ordinances committed in connection with the keeping of chickens or ducks, notwithstanding the issuance of such permit. By applying for a permit under this section the property owner authorizes city officials at all reasonable times and in a reasonable manner to enter upon and inspect the property with respect to which such permit is applied for to determine whether the keeping of chickens or ducks violates this section or any other applicable ordinances.
 
(Ord. No. 5525, § I(6-3), 6-9-2009)


Sec. 10-4. - Revocation of permits to keep chickens and/or ducks.

 
(a)
 
The director of public works shall revoke any permit issued for the keeping of chickens or ducks for violation of any of the conditions stated in
 s e c t i o n 1 0 - 3 or if any of the following conditions are found to exist:
 

(1)

(2)
 

Excessive noise created by the chickens or ducks is audible from adjacent property. The chickens or ducks are not kept in safe and sanitary condition.
 

(3)

(4)
 

The chickens or ducks are not properly confined.

The keeping of the chickens or ducks creates a nuisance.
 

(b)
 

Actions to be taken.
 

(1)



(2)





(3)
 

If a complaint is filed regarding a violation of any of the conditions stated in s e c t i o n 1 0 - 3 or this section, or, in the absence of a complaint, in the discretion of the director of public works, an investigation of any potential violations shall be made by the director of public works or designee.
If the investigation substantiates the existence of a violation of such conditions, a letter shall be sent by certified mail to the property owner notifying the property owner of such violation and that same shall be corrected within not less than five days and that such property owner shall be responsible for notifying the director of public works by certified mail that such violations have been corrected and seeking a reinspection to verify that such violations have been corrected.
In the event the property owner shall fail to notify the director of public works of such correction within five days or in the event that a reinspection does not verify such correction, the permit shall be revoked.
 
(c)
 
Permit revocations under this section may be appealed as follows:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)
 

Appeals must be filed within five days after the revocation notice is mailed by certified mail. Appeals shall be determined following a hearing before the city manager or his designee.
At least five days notice of the hearing shall be given to the property owner by certified mail.

The property owner and any other interested party may appear at the hearing and testify and present evidence concerning the conditions giving rise to the revocation.
 
(Ord. No. 5525, § I(6-4), 6-9-2009)


Sec. 10-5. - Reckless riding, driving of animals.

No person shall ride or drive any animal along or upon a street or other public place in a fast, violent or furious manner, nor shall any person allow a vehicle drawn by animals to strike any person or thing, or allow the animal to remain loose or standing unfastened or unguarded.

(Code 1982, § 6-3; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-6. - Cruelty to animals; abandonment.

No person who is responsible for an animal shall:

 
(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)

(5)

(6)

(7)

(8)
 
Fail to provide adequate food and shelter for the animal for a period of more than 24 hours. Leave an animal without the apparent intent to recover or resume custody.
Fail to provide the animal with proper shelter.

Fail to provide the animal with the opportunity for adequate daily exercise.

Fail to provide the animal with veterinary care when needed to treat injury or illness unless the animal is instead promptly euthanized. Transport an animal in an open vehicle from which it can escape.
Beat, torment, or otherwise abuse an animal.

Cause, instigate, attend, umpire or permit any unlawful exhibition including any dogfight or other combat between animals or between animals and humans within the city limits. Any animal so used shall be seized and impounded. Animals seized shall not be returned to any person participating in or attending the unlawful exhibition.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-4; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-7. - Tethering, prohibited conduct.

It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person controlling or possessing any dog or cat to:

 
(1)

(2)


(3)



(4)
 
Leave a dog or cat tethered outdoors for eight continuous hours or for a total of 12 hours in a 24-hour period.

Tether a dog or cat except by means of a properly fitting harness or collar of nylon or leather construction and a tether in proportion to the size of the animal. The tether must be at least 15 feet in length with a swivel at both ends.
Tether a dog or cat outdoors under conditions where the animal or tether can become entangled on the tether, another animal, or some other object or where the tether can restrict the animal's access to suitable, edible, and sufficient food, clean water (cool in summer and unfrozen in winter), and appropriate shelter.
Tether a dog or cat outdoors in unsafe or unsanitary conditions or when said tether does not allow the animal to defecate or urinate in an area separate from the areas where it must eat, drink, or lie down.
 

(5)
 

Expose a dog or cat to any weather conditions that cause immediate imminent threat to the animal's physical well-being.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-5; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-8. - Gifts of animals.

No person shall sell, give or award, or offer for sale, gift or award six or fewer fowl under one month of age, or a live rabbit under six weeks of age unless the sale, gift or award of such rabbit includes the sale, gift or award of the dam.

(Code 1982, § 6-6; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-9. - Slaughter of stock restricted.

No person other than a person engaged in the business of slaughtering animals in a regular slaughterhouse which is properly equipped for the purpose, shall slaughter any animal in the city.

(Code 1982, § 6-7; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-10. - Horse racing prohibited.

No person shall engage in or participate in any way in horse racing in a public place in the city. (Code 1982, § 6-8; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)

Sec. 10-11. - Defecation on private property, condominium common elements and public property prohibited.

It shall be unlawful for any person owning, controlling, possessing or having the management or care, in whole or in part, of any animal whether licensed or not to allow or permit such animal to defecate upon any private property owned by another, condominium common elements or public property unless such person shall remove all feces so deposited by such animal.
