(Code 1982, § 6-14; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-12. - Dogs banned in public places.

The public works director or his or her designee shall be permitted to temporarily ban animals, for up to 60 days from entering public spaces, including but not limited to city parks. After review by the parks and recreation commission the city council may permanently ban animals from entering public spaces, including but not limited to city parks, if the animals using the space are creating a public health hazard, safety concern, or any other nuisance to the public.

(Ord. No. 5703, § I, 5-28-2013)


Secs. 10-13—10-40. - Reserved.


ARTICLE II. - IMPOUNDMENT



Sec. 10-41. - Impoundment—Authorized in certain cases.

The chief of police and the members of the police department or other persons designated by the city council shall have the power to catch, confine and impound dogs, cats and other animals and it shall be the duty of the chief of police, the members of the police department or other persons designated by the city council to take or have taken and impound or have impounded in a suitable place, the location of which shall be published by posting a card of notice in the offices of the chief of police, city collector and city clerk, all dogs, cats and other animals as follows:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)


(4)



(5)
 

All dogs and cats running at large, whether licensed or unlicensed.

All female dogs and cats, licensed or unlicensed, not securely confined in an enclosed place while in heat.

All dogs, cats and other animals affected with rabies, whether such dog, cat or other animal is running at large or on a leash, and whether licensed or unlicensed.
All dogs, cats and other animals suspected by the rabies control officer, member of the police department or other persons designated by the city council, to be exposed to or affected with rabies, including dogs, cats or other animals known to have been bitten by a rabid animal, whether such dog, cat or other animal is running at large or on a leash, and whether licenses of unlicensed.
All dogs, cats or other animals with vicious propensities.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-9; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)
 

Sec. 10-42. - Same—Fierce, vicious or dangerous dogs running at large.

 
(a)
 
Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
 
Vicious dog means:

 
(1)


(2)


(3)

(4)
 
Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury to, or otherwise threaten the safety of human beings or domestic animals;
Any dog which because of its vicious propensity is capable of inflicting serious physical harm or death to humans and which would constitute a danger to human life or property if it were not kept in a manner required by this Code;
Any dog which, without provocation, attacks or bites, or has attacked or bitten a human being or domestic animal; or Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purposes of dogfighting or any dog trained for dogfighting.
 

(b)






(c)
 

Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, no dog may be deemed "vicious" by reason of a threat, injury or damage which was sustained by a person who at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog or by reason of a threat, injury or damage sustained by a person who, at the time of such threat, injury or damage was teasing, tormenting, abusing or insulting the dog, or was threatening or committing assault or any other bodily harm to the owner or the owners immediate family or their invitees.
Any fierce, vicious or dangerous dog running at large, whether licensed or not, may be impounded for any length of time deemed necessary by the chief of police, or in an emergency in the opinion of the chief of police or any police officer may be shot forthwith. The owner and/or any person having the right of possession of such animal shall be issued a summons to appear in municipal court for violation of this section and, upon conviction, shall be published as provided in s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 . Animal control officers under contract with the city shall have the authority to issue summonses to appear in municipal court for violations of this section only.
 
(Code 1982, § 6-10; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-43. - Same—Redemption fees.

Any dog, cat or other animal captured and impounded under the provisions of s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 1 for the first offense and determined not to be affected with rabies by the director of public health and sanitation may be redeemed to the custody of the owner or other person having the right of possession of such animal by paying the city clerk the sum of $25.00 if not inoculated or licensed and $10.00 if inoculated and licensed. In the event any dog, cat or other animal is impounded for a second or subsequent offense under this section the owner or other person having the right of possession of such animal shall pay to the city clerk the sum of $50.00 if not inoculated and licensed and $25.00 if inoculated and licensed.

(Code 1982, § 6-11; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-44. - Same—Disposition of unredeemed animals.

Any dog, cat or other animal impounded pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 1 and not claimed by its owner or keeper within five days shall be disposed of in such a way or manner as may be directed by the director of public health and sanitation by and with the approval of the city council and the mayor; provided, however, that such dog, cat or other animal may be redeemed by any person before its disposal upon securing a license for such animal and paying the redemption fee provided in s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 3 .

(Code 1982, § 6-12; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-45. - Interference with person enforcing chapter prohibited.

No person shall conceal any animal or interfere with any authorized person in the performance of his duties under this chapter. (Code 1982, § 6-13; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)

Secs. 10-46—10-63. - Reserved.


ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL



Sec. 10-64. - Disposition of afected animals.

The director of public health and sanitation or any person designated by him shall dispose of any dog, cat or other animal affected with rabies and he shall carefully examine or have examined any dog, cat or other animal known to have been bitten by a rabid animal, whether such dog, cat or other animal is running at large or is on a leash, and whether that dog, cat or other animal is licensed or unlicensed.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-31; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-65. - Quarantine of suspected animals.

If a dog or cat has been bitten by another dog or cat, or acts in a manner suggesting rabies, or if the dog or cat is viciously inclined, the owner or keeper of that dog or cat upon receiving a written notice from the police department, and at his own expense, shall have the dog or cat examined and treated by a veterinarian and quarantined for rabies observation. The quarantine shall be for such time as the chief of police or the director of public health and sanitation may specify. The dog or cat so quarantined shall be kept in such a manner as to prevent any human or other animal from being bitten during the period of observation.

(Code 1982, § 6-32; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-66. - Areawide quarantine.

Whenever rabies becomes prevalent in any locality within the city or county, the director of public health and sanitation shall recommend a quarantine order, according to the necessity of the case. The city council may issue such quarantine order pursuant to such recommendation. The director of public health and sanitation shall, during the first week after such quarantine order is issued, take proper measures to inform the people of the city of the existence of such quarantine order and of the penalties attached to the violation of such quarantine order. The quarantine may be terminated by the city council upon the recommendation of the director of public health and sanitation after the necessity therefor shall no longer exist, provided that no quarantine shall remain effective for more than six months from the date of the adoption of the quarantine order, unless such quarantine order is specifically extended by order of the city council.

(Code 1982, § 6-33; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-67. - City's right of entry for enforcement of article.

The director of public health and sanitation, or a person directed or designated by him, shall have the right to enter upon any enclosed property for the purpose of collecting any stray or unlicensed dog, cat or other animal. The director of public health and sanitation, or a person directed or designated by him, may enter any property or premises within a quarantined area during the period of quarantine in order to examine or obtain any dog, cat or other animal suspected of having or having been exposed to rabies. In case entry is refused, the director or the person directed or designated by him under the provision of this section, such person may obtain a warrant upon probable cause from a magistrate or other person empowered to issue such warrants.

(Code 1982, § 6-35; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-68. - Contracts authorized.

The city is empowered to cooperate and contract with the county for the common service of rabies control. All such contracts must be approved by the city council.

(Code 1982, § 6-36; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Secs. 10-69—10-96. - Reserved.


ARTICLE IV. - DOGS AND CATS



Sec. 10-97. - Inoculation required.

Every resident person who owns, controls, manages, possesses or has part interest in any dog or cat over six months of age kept anytime during the year or who permits such a dog or cat to come upon, on or in, and to remain in or about his home, place of business or other premises in the city shall have such dog or cat inoculated against rabies at least once each year.

(Code 1982, § 6-51; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-98. - Running at large prohibited.

No person owning, controlling, keeping, possessing or having any management or care of any dog or cat shall permit such dog or cat to run at large or go off the premises of the owner or keeper thereof, or to be upon any street, alley or other public place within the corporate limits of the city at any time, whether licensed or unlicensed, unless such dog or cat is in the custody and charge of some responsible person and is securely tied or led by a line or leash, so as to effectively prevent such dog or cat from biting, molesting, being with or approaching any person or animal.

(Code 1982, § 6-52; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)
 

Sec. 10-99. - Vicious dog; coninement; leash and muzzle; insurance; posting warning.

 
(a)





(b)


(c)



(d)
 
The owner of any vicious dog, as defined in s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 2 , shall securely confine such dog indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure upon the premises of the owner of the dog. The pen or structure shall have secured sides and a top securely attached to the sides. If the pen or structure has no bottom secured to the sides, the sides shall be embedded into the ground no less than one foot. All such pens or structures shall be adequately lighted and kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
The owner of a vicious dog, as defined in  s e c t i o n  1 0 - 4 2 , shall post a notice on the premises conspicuously visible to the public and noting letters not less than two inches high "vicious dog" or "beware—vicious dog" or "beware of dog."
The owner of a vicious dog, as defined in s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 2 , shall not suffer or permit the dog to go beyond the premises of the owner unless the dog is securely muzzled and restrained by a chain or leash, and under the physical restraint of a person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration, but shall prevent the dog from biting any human or animal
The owner of a vicious dog, as defined in s e c t i o n 1 0 - 4 2 , must within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, provide proof to the city manager of general liability or homeowners liability insurance in the amount of at least $100,000.00 per occurrence, insuring the owner against all claims of any personal injuries inflicted by his vicious dog.
 
(Code 1982, § 6-53; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-100. - License—Fee imposed; inoculation certiicate prerequisite to issuance.

 
(a)



(b)



(c)

(d)
 
An annual license fee of $5.00 for each dog or cat is imposed upon every resident person who owns, controls, manages, possesses or has part interest in any dog or cat kept at any time during the year in the city, or who permits a dog to come upon, on or in, and to remain in or about his home, place of business or other premises in the city.
All applicants for dog or cat licenses, for dogs or cats of more than six months of age, shall present a certificate of inoculation against rabies from a licensed veterinarian, executed sometime during the previous 12-month period, to the licensing official and such official shall not issue such license unless such certificate shall be presented.
The full license fee shall be paid to the city clerk on or before January 1 of each year for the succeeding calendar year or any part of that year. The license fee prescribed herein shall not be charged for a license for any dog trained to assist blind persons when any such dog is actually
being used by a blind person for the purpose of aiding or assisting such blind person in going from place to place.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-54; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-101. - Same—Tags.

 
(a)



(b)



(c)
 
The city clerk shall procure annually a sufficient number of metal tags of convenient size and shape, inscribed with the words "Maplewood, Missouri Animal Tag" and the figures indicating the year for which such license tag is valid. The metal license tags shall be numbered from one upwards.
Any person who is the owner of or has in his possession or custody or control, in whole or in part, any dog or cat shall secure from the city clerk a license tag therefor and keep it securely fastened by means of a collar or of harness of substantial make about the neck of the dog or cat at all times.
Any owner or keeper of a dog or cat who suffers the loss of his dog or cat license tag shall report that loss promptly to the licensing official and exhibit the original license receipt at which time he shall be issued a new license tag upon the payment to the city clerk of a fee of $1.00.
 
(Code 1982, § 6-55; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-102. - Female dogs and cats to be conined while in heat.

All female dogs and cats shall be securely confined while they are in heat. (Code 1982, § 6-56; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)

Secs. 10-103—10-132. - Reserved.


ARTICLE V. - KENNELS



Sec. 10-133. - Deinitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Conducting a kennel means keeping or harboring at any one time more than two dogs or more than two cats, over the age of three months.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-71; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-134. - License.

 
(a)

(b)


(c)


(d)
 
Required. No person shall operate a kennel without having a valid license.

Application. The applicant shall apply for a license hereunder to the city clerk and shall accompany such application with a petition signed by two- thirds of the resident property owners of the city block on which the kennel is to be located, consenting to the establishment of the kennel.
Issuance restricted. No license shall be issued for the establishment of a kennel in an SR, LR or MR zoning district as defined c h a p t e r 5 6 , zoning, if the operation of the kennel includes the sale, exchange or boarding of dogs or cats.
Fee. The license fee shall be $100.00.
 

(Code 1982, § 6-72; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)


Sec. 10-135. - Number of animals restricted.

No more than eight dogs or cats shall be kept in a kennel. (Code 1982, § 6-73; Ord. No. 5295, § I, 11-8-2005)

Chapter 12 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL



Sec. 12-1. - Notiication to the city by Union Electric Company.

For any month when there is a change of user of residential (rate 0.001) or nonresidential (rate 0.043) electric service within the city, Union Electric Company shall notify the public works director (or other appropriate official) of the city, in writing, within seven working days after the end of the month of said changes; indicating the address and apartment or unit number and the names of electric users per service and address and apartment or unit number in whose names service is connected or billed.

(Code 1982, § 16-1; Ord. No. 4594, § 1, 5-11-1993)


Sec. 12-2. - Violations.

It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in violation of any provisions of this chapter, including the codes herein adopted, or to cause, permit or suffer any such violation to be committed. Any such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished with a fine not to exceed $500.00 or 90 days in jail, or both. For purposes of this section, for each day a violation exists, each existing violation shall be considered a separate offense.

(Code 1982, § 7-50; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Secs. 12-3—12-20. - Reserved.


ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY



Sec. 12-21. - Enforcement oicial.

It shall be the duty and responsibility of the director of public works or his designated representative of the city to enforce the provisions of this chapter. No order for correction of any violation under this chapter shall be issued without the approval of the director of public works or his designated representative.

(Code 1972, § 803.01; Code 1982, § 7-16; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984)


Sec. 12-22. - Permit fees.

 
(a)



(b)

(2)

(Code 1972, § 801.04; Code 1982, § 7-17; Ord. No. 4941, §§ I—IV, 5-23-2000)


Sec. 12-23. - Inspections.

 
(a)








(b)





(c)
 
Authorization. The director of public works or his designated representative is authorized and directed to make inspections to determine whether structures, including, without limitation, dwellings and dwelling units, accessory structures and premises located within this city, conform to the requirements of the building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, property maintenance and other codes and ordinances enacted to provide for the safety and appearance of structures and premises. For the purpose of making such inspections, the director of public works or his designated representative is authorized to enter, examine and survey at reasonable times all structures. The owner or occupant of every structure shall give the director of public works or his designated representative access thereto at reasonable times for the purpose of such inspection, examination and survey.
Interference. If any owner, occupant or other person in charge of a structure subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses, impedes, inhibits, interferes with, restricts or obstructs entry and free access to every part of the structure where inspection is authorized by this chapter, the director of public works or his designated representative may seek, in a court of competent jurisdiction, an order that such owner, occupant or other person in charge cease and desist with such interference.
Initiation. Inspections pursuant to this section shall be initiated upon receipt of an application for inspection under the following circumstances:
 

(1)






(2)


(3)






(4)
 

Whenever there is a change of owner or occupant of a structure, other than a multiple dwelling, or a residential rental unit for which a valid certificate of compliance exists as stated in subsection (e) of this section, the director of public works shall cause an inspection to be made of said structure to determine that the provisions of this chapter are complied with. If no violations are noted, the director of public works will issue a certificate of compliance which shall be valid until the next change of ownership or occupancy unless revoked by the director of public works for good cause. These inspections will be made upon receipt of an application for inspection and accompanying fee.
Owners contemplating a change of ownership or occupancy may request the director of public works to make the inspection at a mutually agreed time.
An owner or an occupant may request an inspection at any time to determine if there are any violations of this chapter. The owner or occupant will be notified of violations with the understanding that abatement of internal violations will not be enforced, except those of an emergency nature constituting a health or safety hazard, until such time as there is a change of owner or occupancy, but that external conditions contributing to substantial blight or the appearance of blight or that are detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of residents of the city must be abated within a reasonable time as provided in sections 1 2 - 2 6 through 1 2 - 3 4 .
The director of public works may make external inspections at any time when he has reason to believe that conditions exist which contribute to substantial blight or the appearance of substantial blight or which are detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of residents of the city. The owner or occupant will be given a reasonable time to abate any violations as provided in sections 1 2 - 2 6 through 1 2 - 3 4 . No inspection fee will be charged.
 
(d)
 
Fees.
 

(1)
 

The fees for subsections (c)(1) and (2) of this section shall be as follows:
 

a.	For the first unit, $50.00.

b.	For each additional unit, $10.00.
 

(2)
 

Whenever an inspection of a multifamily dwelling or residential rental property indicates evidence of a violation of any provision of this chapter and written notice has been given to the owner to commence a remedy of the condition therein specified, a reinspection fee of
$25.00 for the first unit and $5.00 for each additional unit shall be paid to the city clerk prior to every reinspection that is required that occurs after 30 days from date of the issuance of the notice of violation and correction order until the multifamily dwelling or residential rental property is determined to comply with the provisions of this chapter. The fee may be waived by the director of public works due to the need for additional time caused by the requirement to employ skilled tradesmen to make the repairs or seasonal weather conditions making exterior repairs impossible.
 
(e)
 
Annual inspection of multifamily dwellings and residential rental property.
 

(1)
 

No person shall operate a multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property, unless a current certificate of compliance is issued for the specifically named multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property.
 

(2)


(3)





(4)



(5)



(6)


(7)



(8)



(9)






(10)
 

Every certificate of compliance for a multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property shall be issued for a period of one year unless revok cause.
No certificate of compliance shall be issued unless the owner or agent agrees in the application to such inspections, pursuant to this section, as may be required to determine whether the multiple-family dwelling or residential property in connection with the certificate of compliance is sought is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, and also provides the city with a current list of tenants and occupants.
No certificate of compliance shall be issued unless the owner or agent has first made application for inspection, and the completed application form is accompanied by the payment of an inspection fee, and the applicant agrees to require all new tenants to obtain an occupancy permit before taking occupancy.
No certificate of compliance shall be issued unless the applicant designates an agent who shall either reside or have a place of business in the city or in the county as authorized to accept service of notice of violation of the provisions of this article and for service or process pursuant to this article.
The application for annual inspection shall be made no more than 60 days and no less than 30 days prior to the expiration of the current certificate of compliance.
Whenever, upon inspection of the multiple-family dwelling or residential real property, it is found that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any applicable rules and regulations pursuant thereto, the owner or agent shall be served  with a notice of such violation in the manner provided in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 6 .
At the end of the time allowed for correction of any violation cited, there shall be a reinspection of the multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property to determine that, if such conditions have not been corrected within a reasonable time, there will be prosecution of such violation as provided in sections 1 2 - 3 1 through 1 2 - 3 4 .
Every owner or agent shall have a current and valid certificate of compliance before they sell, transfer, lease or otherwise dispose of any multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property and shall have advised the new owner or agent that annual inspections are required and that an occupancy permit is required of each new occupant before taking occupancy. The name and address of the new owner or agent succeeding to the ownership or control of such multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property shall be given to the city by written notice.
The owner or agent of a multiple-family dwelling or residential rental property shall notify all occupants of inspections to be made, shall be present for inspections, and have means to gain entry to each dwelling unit and/or make arrangements with occupants to be present for inspections.
 
(f)
 
Annual inspection of vacant buildings, vacant dwellings and dwelling units.
 

(1)


(2)



(3)

(4)
 

No owner or agent shall maintain any vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit after 180 days of the date of vacancy without a current certificate of compliance.
Prior to obtaining a certificate of compliance, the owner or agent shall obtain an inspection of the vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit to determine whether a certificate of compliance may be issued. The process for obtaining an inspection shall be the same as set forth in subsection (e) of this section, except that the submission of a list of tenants is not applicable.
The fees for inspection shall be the same as set forth in subsection (d) of this section.

A certificate of compliance shall be issued if the owner has paid the applicable fees and the vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit complies with the following provisions:
 
a.	The 1993 BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, as adopted, amended and codified in article III, division 2 of this chapter.
Adoption of the property maintenance code, except that the regulations contained in the following paragraphs and chapters shall not apply:
1.	PM-303.4.2 Landscape materials;

2.	PM-303.11.2 Openable windows;

3.	PM-304.12 Insect screens;

4.	PM-305.1 General (Interior Structure);

5.	PM-305.3 Interior surfaces;

6.	 C h a p t e r 4 Light, Ventilation and Occupancy Limitations;

7.	 C h a p t e r  5  Plumbing Facilities and Fixture Requirements;

8.	 C h a p t e r  6  Mechanical and Electrical Requirements; and

9.	 C h a p t e r  7  Fire Safety Requirements.

b.	In addition to the 1993 BOCA National Property Maintenance Code, with the above referenced exceptions, the vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling shall comply with the following regulations:
1.	Water service to the structure shall be turned off at the tee head, except in the case of a vacant unit, the plumbing shall be so winterized as to prevent the plumbing pipes from freezing;
 

2.	Natural gas service shall be turned off at the tee head, except in the case of a vacant unit, the natural gas service shall be turned off to prevent leakage;
3.	No flammable materials shall be stored inside the structure;

4.	The interior premises shall be maintained free of rubbish and garbage;

5.	All floors shall be maintained in a safe condition; and

6.	All exterior doors shall be locked.
 

(5)


(6)





(7)



(8)


(9)
 

Every certificate of compliance for a vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit shall be issued for a period of one year unless revoked for good cause.
The owner or agent of the vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit shall have 30 days from the issuance of the notice of a violation to make all repairs and remedy any conditions found which prevent the issuance of a certificate of compliance. Additional time to correct violations, not exceeding 60 days after the initial 30 days allotted for corrections or repairs, may be granted by the director of public works if the owner or agent has demonstrated by evidence of work already performed that work is progressing continuously to completion.
If the condition of the vacant building, vacant dwelling or dwelling unit is so deteriorated or unsafe that in the opinion of the director of public works the structure may be declared a public nuisance as set forth in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 , then the director of public works may set another schedule for compliance, or may undertake emergency measures pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 5 .
If the owner or agent does not make all repairs and remedy any conditions which prevent the issuance of certificate of compliance, the director of public works is authorized to seek compliance with the provisions of this chapter as authorized in  s e c t i o n  1 - 1 1 .
A transfer of ownership of a vacant dwelling shall comply with the regulations set forth in subsection (g) of this section.
 

(g)
 

Transfer of ownership.
 

(1)












(2)


(3)
 

It shall be unlawful for the owner of any structure or his agent to sell, transfer, lease or otherwise dispose thereof to another until he shall have secured a certificate of compliance, and such owner shall be responsible for abating any violations necessary for a certificate of compliance to be issued, unless such owner or agent provides the grantee (including a lessee or mortgagee) with a true copy of the notice of any violation or compliance order which must be abated before a certificate of compliance is issued and provides the city with a signed and notarized statement from such grantee acknowledging the notice of violation or compliance order and fully accepting the responsibility, without condition, for making the corrections or repairs required within a reasonable time established by the city manager or director of public works, not to exceed 90 days. If such corrections or repairs are not completed within such time (as may be extended by the city manager or director of public works for good cause shown) the city may hold both the seller or lessor and the grantee responsible for such corrections or repairs. For dwellings and dwelling units, the owner or agent shall advise the grantee that such grantee must secure an occupancy permit if the premises are to be occupied.
A grantee who has received actual or constructive notice of the existence of a notice of violation or compliance order, whether or not shall be bound by such notice as of the date of the transfer without further service of notice upon him.
This section shall not apply to transfers of real property wherein the grantee commits in writing to the city manager or director of public works that the structures on the land so transferred will be demolished within 90 days after the transfer, provided that the structures are so demolished within such time. The city manager or director of public works may, upon good cause shown, grant an extension for a period of time not to exceed 90 days. If at the expiration of such 90-day period of time and any extension thereof the buildings shall not have been demolished, then the provisions of this section shall apply.
 
(Code 1972, § 803.02; Code 1982, § 7-18; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4067, § 1, 10-28-1980; Ord. No. 4073, § 1, 12-9-1980; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-
1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 4941, §§ V, VI, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 4974, §§ I, II, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 5085, §§ I, II, 1-
14-2003; Ord. No. 5160, §§ I, II, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 5464, § I, 3-25-2008)


Sec. 12-24. - Access by owner or operator.

Every occupant of a structure or premises shall give the owner or operator thereof, or his agent or employee, access to any part of such structure or premises at reasonable times for the purpose of making such inspection, maintenance, repairs or alterations as are necessary to comply with the provisions of this chapter.

(Code 1972, § 803.03; Code 1982, § 7-19; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-1994)


Sec. 12-25. - Occupancy permit.

 
(a)
 
Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to hereinafter occupy, or for any owner or agent thereof to permit the occupancy of, any dwelling or dwelling unit, or addition thereto, or part thereof, for any purpose:
 
(1)

(2)
 
Until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the director of public works; If such certificate of occupancy has been revoked.
 
The certificate of occupancy shall be issued when the occupancy complies with all the provisions of this chapter.
 

(b)







(c)



(d)


(e)

(f)


(g)
 

Conditional. The director of public works may, at his discretion, issue a conditional occupancy permit under circumstances where a buyer has made stating that he will correct deficiencies within a specified time. Under no circumstances shall a conditional occupancy permit be issued if the listed v under the discretion of the public works director, are deemed to be health or safety issues. No conditional occupancy permit shall be issued for ren units. Once a conditional occupancy permit is issued, the dwelling may then be occupied while repairs are being made. If the deficiencies are not co within the time specified, the conditional occupancy certificate may be revoked. At such time as the dwelling complies with all the provisions of this occupancy permit will be issued as provided in subsection (a) of this section.
Application; required information. Every application shall provide basic identifying information, and other identifying information determined to be necessary by the director of public works to verify the number and identity of the occupants; such information may include photographic identification of adult occupants and a copy of signed leases in the case of rental property.
Applicability. This section shall not apply to any occupancy in existence on November 11, 1975, nor shall a family be considered in violation of this section by reason of births or deaths within a family, nor by reason of the return of a family member.
Fee. The fee for such occupancy permit shall be $15.00 for each dwelling unit occupied.

False information. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make any false statement in his application for an occupancy permit as to the names, ages, relationship, or number of occupants who will occupy the premises.
Revocation. The certificate of occupancy shall always be subject to this Code. Noncompliance with the regulations of this Code shall be deemed a violation subject to the penalties set forth herein, and in addition the director of public works or his authorized representative shall be empowered to revoke the certificate of occupancy for the unit in question, until such time as the violations are corrected and in compliance.
 
(Code 1972, § 803.04; Code 1982, § 7-20; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 4941, § VIII, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 5085, § III, 1-14-2003; Ord. No. 5464, § II, 3-25-2008)


Sec. 12-26. - Noncompliance—Notice to be given.

 
(a)



(b)


(c)
 
Notice of violation. Whenever the director of public works or his designated representative finds evidence of a violation of any provision of this chapter, he shall give notice of same in writing, delivered in person or via first class mail to the owner or agent of the building, structure, and/or property as shown on the city records.
Notice of public nuisance. In addition to or as an alternative to the notice of violation in subsection (a) of this section, a notice of public nuisance may be given pursuant to, and in the manner provided in, s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 .
Stop work order. A stop work order shall be posted where the public works director or his designated representative determines that any of the following exists:
 
(1)

(2)

(3)

(4)
 
Work has been started prior to the acquisition of a permit as required by this Code. Work being done is outside the scope of a previously issued permit.
Work is being done in an unsafe and/or dangerous manner.

Work being done is not in compliance with any requirements of this Code, including any codes adopted thereby.
 

(d)



(e)
 

Notice to owner. The public works director or his authorized representative shall give written notice of the stop work order to the owner, authorized representative or person doing the work. Notwithstanding sections 118.1 and 118.2 of the BOCA National Building Code, such written notice may be given by posting the property with the stop work order notice.
Continuance of work after issuance of stop work order. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, and the owner of the property or structure who permits any such prohibited work, shall be liable for a fine as provided in  s e c t i o n  1 - 1 1 .
 
(Code 1972, § 803.05; Code 1982, § 7-21; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994)


Sec. 12-27. - Same—Correction.

 
(a)






(b)
 
Remedy of defects. Unless a shorter time period is provided by this Code, the owner of any building shall have 30 days from the issuance of the notice provided for in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 6 in which to commence a remedy of the condition therein specified, and shall proceed continuously without unnecessary delay to completion, except when emergency conditions shall require immediate action as provided in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 5 (emergency measures); provided, however, that the director of public works or his designated representative, may, at his discretion, extend the time for compliance with any such notice.
Reinspection. At the time when the violations have allegedly been brought into compliance by either notification or lapse of time, the director of public works or the designated representative shall reinspect the building or structure within ten working days. At this time, the director shall make a complete inspection, taking particular notice that the violations previously noted have been brought into compliance, and that no new violations have come into existence in the time which has elapsed since the first inspection.
 
(Code 1972, § 803.06; Code 1982, § 7-22; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4068, § 1, 10-28-1980; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-
1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-1994)
 

Sec. 12-28. - Broken glass—Dwelling units.

 
(a)






(b)





(c)
 
Temporary repairs. Every window, glazed exterior door, exterior transom, or exterior sidelight shall be provided with properly installed glass or other approved glazing material. In the event of breakage, the owner shall cause the immediate removal of broken glass from the premises and shall temporarily board up the affected openings with suitable material to provide protection from the elements and to prevent entry of birds or animals and to provide security to occupants or contents of the building. Within ten days after boarding up, the owner shall cause the boarding material to be removed, and all affected openings shall be simultaneously reglazed by the owner.
Provision of adequate lighting and ventilation. Adequate ventilation and natural lighting shall be provided for all occupied dwelling units. Whenever any exterior openings are found boarded up, it shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designated representative to notify the owner or agent of this requirement giving him a period of not more than ten working days in which to properly replace the broken glass or cause the dwelling unit to be vacated. This notice shall be given in the manner required by s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 6 .
Specifications. Since the presence of boarded up buildings, particularly those where the boarding is unpainted or applied in an insecure, careless, or unpresentable fashion, invites vandalism, and creates a blighting influence which adversely affects the general welfare of the people of this city, it is hereby required that all boarding up of exterior openings be accomplished in a neat workmanlike manner with not less than one-half- inch thick, weather-resistant plywood, cut to fit within the openings, fastened in place as securely as possible, and suitably coated with an appropriate neutral color blending with or harmonizing with the exterior colors of the building as inconspicuously as possible. It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his designated representative to notify the owner or agent of any boarded-up dwelling unit not complying with the above requirements, of the necessity of immediate compliance and ordering him to replace the broken glass, or repair, replace or paint the boarding. This notice shall be given in the manner required in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 6 .
 
(Code 1972, § 803.09; Code 1982, § 7-25; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984)


Sec. 12-29. - Same—Buildings other than dwelling units.

 
(a)


(b)



(c)


(d)



(e)
 
Every window, glazed exterior door, exterior transom, or exterior sidelight on all buildings within the city, except dwelling units, shall be provided with properly installed glass or other approved glazing material.
In the event of breakage, the owner of such building shall cause the immediate removal of all broken glass from the premises and shall temporarily board up the affected openings with suitable material to provide protection from the elements and to prevent entry of birds, animals or persons, and to provide security to the occupants or contents of the building.
Within ten days after boarding up, the owner shall cause the boarding material to be removed, and all affected openings shall be simultaneously reglazed by the owner.
In the event of breakage of poster case glass, the owner of the building shall cause all broken glass to be removed from the premises and shall temporarily board up such poster case. Within ten days after boarding up, the owner shall cause the boarding material to be removed and either simultaneously reglaze the affected opening or remove the entire poster case and refinish the affected building surface.
This section does not apply to dwelling units within the city since the same is covered by s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 8 .
 

(Code 1972, §§ 805.01—805.04, 805.04A, 805.04B; Code 1982, § 7-26; Ord. No. 4066, § 1, 10-28-1980; Ord. No. 4074, § 1, 12-9-1980)


Sec. 12-30. - Holiday decorations.

All exterior holiday decorations must be removed 60 days after the holiday. Any exterior holiday decorations left up longer than 60 days shall be in violation of this Code subject to the general penalty outlined in s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 .

(Code 1982, § 7-27; Ord. No. 5282, § I, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-31. - Prosecution of violation.

 
(a)
 
In case any violation of this chapter is not remedied within the prescribed time period, the director of public works or his designated representative may use any or all of the following remedies:
 
(1)

(2)


(3)



(4)

(5)
 
Restrain the owner from performing or allowing any further execution of pending work on the building or structure;

Prevent the occupation or use of the building, structure or part thereof erected, installed or altered in violation of, or not in compliance with, the provisions of this chapter or in violation of a plan or specification under which an approval, permit or certificate was issued;
Require the removal of any building, structure, or part thereof, which is erected, constructed, installed or altered in violation of, or not in compliance with, the provisions of this chapter or in violation of a plan or specification under which an approval, permit or certificate was issued, or when any of the above is done without obtaining the required permits from the city;
Enforce the penalty provisions of this chapter or of s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 or any other penalty provisions available to the city;

Request that the city attorney institute an appropriate action or proceeding at law (to compel compliance or otherwise) against the person or firm responsible for the failure to comply.
 
(b)
 
In addition to the remedies available under subsection (a) of this section, for any violation that is a public nuisance as defined in  s e c t i o n  1 2 - 3 2 ,
 

the director of public works or his representative may order the violation corrected or the building demolished at the owner's expense, as provided in sections 1 2 - 3 2 through 1 2 - 3 4 . The director of public works shall not be obligated to pursue any of the remedies in subsection (a) of this section as a condition to pursuing remedies under this subsection (b).
 
(c)
 
The procedures and remedies in this chapter are independent of and in addition to:
 

(1)

(2)
 

Any actions authorized by c h a p t e r 3 4 , article VIII (nuisances) or successor provisions; and

Any remedy for violations provided in the building code as adopted by article III of this chapter.
 

(d)
 

Failure to obtain occupancy permit. A property owner, landlord or agent who allows a tenant to move initially into their property without an occupancy permit shall be summoned into municipal court and shall be subject to the following minimum penalties:
 

First ofense	
$ 50.00 plus court costs

Second ofense	
75.00 plus court costs

Third and subsequent ofenses	
100.00 plus court costs



(Code 1972, § 803.14; Code 1982, § 7-28; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 5085, § IV, 1-14-2003; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-32. - Public nuisance.

 
(a)
 
Declaration. Any structure found to have any of the following defects shall be deemed to be detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the city and shall be declared a public nuisance:
 
(1)


(2)


(3)


(4)


(5)



(6)

(7)

(8)
 
Bearing wall, earth retaining wall, column, or other vertical structural member which leans or buckles to such an extent that it is likely to partially or completely collapse and injure the occupants or members of the public.
Floor, roof, wall, structural member or structural connection which is overloaded or which has insufficient strength to be safe for the purpose used so as to be likely to collapse and injure the occupants or members of the public.
A building, structure or part thereof, or property, which is so attached that it is unsafe or dangerous to either the occupants or the general public.
A building, structure or part thereof, or property which has been so damaged by fire, wind, or other causes, so as to become unsafe or dangerous to the occupants or the general public.
A building, structure or part thereof, or property which because of the degree of disrepair or lack of maintenance is so unsanitary, vermin or rat infested, filthy or contaminated, or lacking in ventilation, sanitary facilities, heating facilities or other code required equipment that is hazardous to the health or safety of the occupants or members of the public.
Any violation of the zoning code.

Where there has been a cessation of normal construction of any structure for a period of more than one year.

Any one or more violations of any provision of this chapter which is detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city.
 

(b)



(c)
 

Mandatory demolition or repair of a public nuisance. The following steps shall be taken to effect the mandatory demolition or repair of a building, structure or part thereof, or property which is deemed to be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the general public and which is declared a public nuisance.
Notice of declaration of nuisance. A notice of declaration of nuisance and prehearing order shall be prepared in substantially the following form: NOTICE OF DECLARATION OF NUISANCE AND PRE-HEARING ORDER
THE STRUCTURE OR STRUCTURES DESCRIBED BELOW HAS BEEN DECLARED A NUISANCE

(Insert address or other adequate description of the building or structure.) (Use either or both of the following paragraphs.)
(1)	NO PERSON MAY OCCUPY THIS BUILDING, OR ANY PART THEREOF, AFTER	, 20	. After such date, no person shall occupy, enter, refuse to leave, or remain in this building or any part thereof, except persons directly employed in securing, repairing or removing such building.

(2)	THIS STRUCTURE OR PROPERTY MUST BE REPAIRED TO CURE THE FOLLOWING DEFECTS:
 

WORK MUST BEGIN ON OR BEFORE	, 20	AND PROCEED CONTINUOUSLY WITHOUT UNNECESSARY DELAY TO
COMPLETION. Upon failure to repair or demolish as herein required, the director of public works may, after hearing, order repairs to be made and the cost charged to the owner of this property as a special tax lien.

AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO THE REPAIRS DESCRIBED ABOVE, THIS STRUCTURE MAY BE DEMOLISHED AND REMOVED FROM THE PREMISES NOT LATER THAN	, 20	.
 

(d)

(e)






(f)





(g)










(h)
 

Posting. A copy of the notice of declaration of nuisance and pre-hearing order shall be posted in a prominent place on the premises.

Service. The notice of declaration of nuisance and pre-hearing order shall be served on the affected parties, consisting of owner, occupants, lessee, mortgagee, agent and all persons having an interest in the property, all as shown by the records of the county recorder of deeds. The notice may be served personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested, or if service cannot be had by either of these modes of service, then by at least one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The affected parties shall have not less than 30 days from the date of service to complete demolition or to begin the repairs.
Notice of hearing. If the affected parties fail to commence work on repairs or complete demolition within the time specified, or fail to proceed continuously with the work without unnecessary delay, the director of public works shall call a hearing upon the matter, giving the affected parties ten days written notice of the hearing. Said notice may be served personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested, or if service cannot be had by either of these modes of service, then by at least one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city.
Hearing. The director of public works or the duly designated representative of the director of public works shall conduct a full and adequate hearing. Any affected party may be represented by counsel and all affected parties shall have an opportunity to be heard. After the hearing, if the evidence supports a finding that the building or structure is a nuisance and detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the city, the director of public works shall issue a post-hearing order making specific findings of fact based on competent and substantial evidence which shows the building or structure to be a nuisance and detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city, and ordering the building or structure to be demolished and removed, or repaired. The post-hearing order shall be served in the same manner as the notice of declaration of nuisance and pre-hearing order. If the evidence does not support a finding that the building or structure is a nuisance or detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the city, no order shall be issued.
Upon failure to obey order. If any order of the director of public works is not obeyed within the time specified therein, the director of public  works shall cause such building or structure to be vacated and repaired or demolished as provided in his order. The director of public works shall certify the cost for such action, including all administrative costs, to the city clerk, who shall cause a special tax bill against the property to be prepared, filed and collected, as outlined in this section.
 
(Code 1972, § 803.17; Code 1982, § 7-29; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 4889, § I, II, 4-13-1999; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-33. - Special tax bill.

If the director of public works issues an order whereby the building or structure is demolished, secured or repaired, or the property is cleaned up, the cost of performance shall be certified to the city clerk or officer in charge of finance who shall cause a special tax bill therefor against the property to be prepared, filed and collected by the city collector or other official collecting taxes, unless the building or structure is demolished, secured or repaired by a contractor pursuant to an order issued by the city and such contractor files a mechanic's lien against the property where the dangerous building is located. The contractor may enforce this lien as provided in RSMo 429.010 to 429.360. Except as provided in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 8 , at the request of the taxpayer, the tax bill may be paid in
installments over a period of not more than ten years. Such assessment shall bear interest of nine percent per annum, or, if such amount exceeds the maximum rate that the law will allow, then at such maximum rate, until paid. The tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be deemed a personal debt against the
property owner and also shall be a lien on the property until paid.

(Code 1972, § 803.17; Code 1982, § 7-30; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 4889, § III, 4-13-1999; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-34. - Appeal to circuit court of county.

The decision by the director of public works or his designated representative made following a hearing held pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 , may be appealed by a party aggrieved thereby to the circuit court of the county, pursuant to RSMo ch. 536; provided that any party so aggrieved, other than the city, may either appeal directly to the circuit court of the county or to the housing board of appeals of this city. The decision by the housing board of appeals may be appealed by any party aggrieved thereby to the circuit court of the county pursuant to RSMo ch. 536.

(Code 1972, § 803.18; Code 1982, § 7-31; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-35. - Emergency measures.

 
(a)
 
Applicability. When any dwelling unit has become so damaged by fire, wind or other causes, or has become so unsafe, unhealthful or unsanitary,
 

that, in the opinion of the director of public works or his designated representative, life or health is immediately endangered by the occupation of the dwelling unit or property, the director of public works or his designated representative is hereby authorized and empowered to revoke without notice any occupancy permit for such dwelling unit and to order and require the occupants to vacate the same forthwith and to order the owner or agent to proceed immediately with the corrective work and repairs required to make the dwelling unit temporarily safe and fit for human habitation, whether or not a notice of violation has been given as described in this chapter, and whether or not legal procedures  described by this Code have been instituted.
 
(b)
 
Procedures. If the owner does not complete such corrective work or repairs when and as necessary to avoid an immediate danger to the health, safety, or welfare of any person, the director of public works or his designated representative may take emergency measures to vacate and repair the structure or otherwise remove the immediate danger at the owner's cost.
 
(Code 1972, § 803.20; Code 1982, § 7-32; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 1, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 4645, § 1, 5-10-
1994; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Sec. 12-36. - Registration of agents.

Owners of residential property in the city who are not residents of the city or the county shall designate an agent who shall either reside or have a place of business in the city or the county, as authorized to accept service of notice under the provisions of this article. It shall be the owner's responsibility to register such agent with the director of public works.

(Code 1972, § 803.11; Code 1982, § 7-33; Ord. No. 3784, § 1, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-
2005)


Sec. 12-37. - Confict of interest.

No person shall be appointed or remain in office as director of public works or his designated representative, or inspector or member of the housing board of appeals who is engaged directly or indirectly in the business of repair, construction or alteration in the city.

(Code 1972, § 803.21; Code 1982, § 7-34; Ord. No. 3784, § 2, 11-14-1974; Ord. No. 4090, § 2, 5-26-1981; Ord. No. 4163, § 1, 1-24-1984; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-
2005)


Sec. 12-38. - Proceeds of insurance.

 
(a)






(b)
 
If there are proceeds of any insurance policy based upon a covered claim payment made for damage or loss to a building or other structure caused by or arising out of any fire, explosion, or other casualty loss, the insurer shall withhold from the covered claim payment an amount equal to 25 percent of the covered claim payment, and shall pay such moneys to the city to deposit into an interest-bearing account. Any named mortgagee on the insurance policy shall maintain priority over any obligation under this section. This section shall apply only to a covered claim payment which is in excess of 50 percent of the face value of the policy covering a building or other structure.
The city shall release the proceeds and any interest which has accrued on such proceeds received under subsection (a) of this section to the insured or as the terms of the policy and endorsements thereto provide within 30 days after receipt of such insurance moneys, unless the city has instituted legal proceedings under the provisions of s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 . If the city has proceeded under the provisions of s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 , then:
 
(1)



(2)
 
To the extent permitted under section RSMo 67.410, the city may apply the proceeds (and any interest which has accrued thereon) to the costs necessary to comply with the provisions of s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 for the removal of the building or structure, less salvage value, to board up the building or structure, or to clean up the property after a casualty loss; and
All moneys in excess of that necessary to comply with the provisions of s e c t i o n 1 2 - 3 2 for the removal of the building or structure, less salvage value, to board up the building or structure, or to clean up the property after a casualty loss, shall be paid to the insured.
 
(c)
 
If there are no proceeds of any insurance policy as set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, at the request of the taxpayer, the tax bill may be paid in installments over a period of not more than ten years. The tax bill from the date of its issuance shall be a lien on the property until paid.
 
(Code 1982, § 7-35; Ord. No. 4889, § IV, 4-13-1999; Ord. No. 5282, § II, 9-27-2005)


Secs. 12-39—12-64. - Reserved.


DIVISION 2. - DESIGN AND REVIEW BOARD



Sec. 12-65. - Composition; appointment; terms; oicers.

 
(a)
 
There is hereby created a board to be known as the design and review board which will consist of five members. The members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council and shall serve without compensation for terms of three years. The initial appointment of members shall be staggered so that one member will have a one-year term, one member a two-year term, and three members a three-year term.
 

Thereafter, all terms shall be for a period of three years.
 

(b)


(c)
 

The membership of the design and review board shall consist of five members of which three members shall be representatives of the business community. At least three members of the board must be citizens of the city.
The mayor shall appoint the chairperson of the design and review board and the members shall elect their own secretary.
 

(Code 1982, § 7-41; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-66. - Plan approval for commercial, industrial, institutional or multiple-family dwelling.

All applications for building permits and all plans for proposed exterior alterations, repairs or maintenance that will affect the exterior appearance of a building, including fences and signs, shall be submitted to the design and review board prior to issuance of a building permit or the commencement of such work for approval if:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)
 

Same is commercial, industrial, institutional or multiple dwelling in character; Same is a new fence, or sign construction in the city; or
The building official finds that the proposed building structure, improvement, fence or sign would be detrimental to the stability and values of surrounding property by reason of its incompatibility and inappropriateness thereto, is inharmonious and inconsistent with the surrounding property or is inconsistent with the zoning plan and the map and regulations thereunder.
 

(Code 1982, § 7-42; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-67. - Plan approval for single-family residential.

All applications for building permits and all plans for proposed exterior alterations, excluding retaining walls (less than four feet in height), decks, storage buildings, fences and swimming pools that will affect the exterior appearance of a building, shall be submitted to the design and review board prior to issuance of a building permit or the commencement of such work for approval.

(Code 1982, § 7-43; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-68. - Application for building permit—Submissions; board action required.

In the event the approval of the design and review board is required under  s e c t i o n  1 2 - 6 6 , the building official shall, upon receipt of legal processing fee, as specified in this Code, from the applicant, no more than seven days after the filing of the application for the building permit, certify such application, together with all attached plans, specifications, plot diagrams and other instruments required by law to the design and review board by delivering same to the chairperson thereof. Within 21 days after such delivery, the board shall, in writing, deliver to the building official its approval, conditional approval, rejection or disapproval of the said application. Failure of the board to act within said 21-day period shall constitute approval of said application. Such approval shall be deemed to include any stipulations as may have been applied by the building official upon his plan examination. Under the terms of this section, resubmission by the applicant of a conditionally approved, rejected or disapproved application shall constitute a new application.

(Code 1982, § 7-44; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-69. - Same—Consideration by board; hearing.

Following the certification of such application and attached documents to the board, said board shall consider same and may hold a hearing on the matter, written notice of which shall be given the applicant at least five days in advance of said hearing, as to time, place and purpose and at which the applicant shall be accorded an opportunity to be heard.

(Code 1982, § 7-45; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-70. - Same—Conditions.

The board shall approve or conditionally approve the application if it finds:

 
(1)

(2)
 
The application conforms to the zoning plan and map; and

With respect to single-family dwellings and structures, the subject matter of the application, if erected, would not be detrimental, inharmonious or inconsistent with the property in the surrounding area. Such finding shall be based on a determination that neither of the following conditions will be created by erection of the proposed dwelling or fence:
 
a.	Excessive similarity to any other structure existing or for which a permit has been issued, or to any other structure included in the same permit application, facing upon the same side of the street and within 250 feet of the proposed site unless differing substantially in overall exterior design or in four or more of the following features of exterior design and appearance:
1.	Landscaping;
 

2.	Combination of materials;

3.	Texture of materials;

4.	Site setting;

5.	Location of carports and garages;

6.	Finished grade levels;

7.	Type of roof;

8.	Height of roof;

9.	Number and size of windows.

b.	Excessive and unreasonable dissimilarity or inappropriateness in relation to any other structure existing or for which a building permit has been issued, or to any other structure included in the same permit application, facing upon the same side of the street and within 250 feet of the proposed site in respect to one or more of the following features:
1.	Cubical contents;

2.	Gross floor area;

3.	Height of building or height of roof;

4.	Other significant design features such as material or quality or architectural design, provided that a finding of excessive dissimilarity or inappropriateness exists, but further that it is of such a nature as to be expected to provoke beyond reasonable doubt an adverse effect on the stability and value of surrounding property, and that finding is not based on personal preference as to taste or choice of architectural style.
 
(3)



(4)
 
With respect to fences (excluding single-family residential) the subject matter of the application, if erected, would not be detrimental, inharmonious or inconsistent with the property in the surrounding area; that its erection shall not injure the rights of adjacent property owners nor shall the welfare and safety of the public be adversely affected.
With respect to the erection, improvement or alteration of commercial, industrial, institutional or multiple-dwelling buildings and structures, including signs, that same shall be in the interest of the public health, welfare, safety and morals; and harmonious and consistent with the property in the surrounding area with respect to the following factors:
 
a.	Use of space.

1.	Ratio of structures to the building site;

2.	Position of structures and other improvements on the site;

3.	Relation of structures and other improvements to adjoining properties and streets;

4.	Landscaping;

5.	Effective screening, such as fences, walls or landscaping;

6.	All other factors contributing to the most desirable use of space;

7.	Parking facilities.

b.	Design.

1.	Plans and elevations;

2.	Color, material and texture;

3.	Relation to the site and to adjoining properties;

4.	Signs as related to proposed structures and adjoining properties;

5.	Landscaping, fences, garden walls and entrances;

6.	Other factors pertaining to overall design and appearance.

(Code 1982, § 7-46; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Sec. 12-71. - Appeals.

Appeals from the granting or denial of a building permit by the building official shall be to the board of adjustment as is in such cases provided by law. (Code 1982, § 7-47; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)

Sec. 12-72. - Consultation; advice.

The design and review board shall, to the greatest extent practicable, upon request, furnish advice and consultation to applicants for building permits or other persons contemplating building or development in the city.

(Code 1982, § 7-48; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)
 

Sec. 12-73. - Architect or engineer certiication.

All plans and specifications filed for building permits shall be compiled, stamped or signed by a registered architect or engineer if estimated cost of construction, as shown on the application for permit, exceeds $25,000.00.

(Code 1982, § 7-49; Ord. No. 4221, § 1, 8-13-1985)


Secs. 12-74—12-91. - Reserved.

Section 107.2 Form is hereby amended to insert at the beginning "Unless otherwise provided in the Maplewood Code of Ordinances . . ."

Section 107.3 Method of service is hereby amended to insert at the beginning "Unless otherwise provided in the Maplewood Code of Ordinances . . ."

Section 201.3 Terms defined in other codes. Delete all references to code within the subsection, and insert the following codes in their place: the Building Code of St. Louis County, Missouri, the Plumbing Code of St. Louis County, Missouri, the Mechanical Code of St. Louis County, Missouri, the International Fire Code, or the Maplewood Code of Ordinances, including the Maplewood Zoning Code.

Section 202 General Definitions. Add the following definitions:

Agent. A person authorized to accept service of notice who either resides or has a place of business within St. Louis County or the City of St. Louis.

Accessory structure. A structure subordinate to the main or principal structure, which is not used for living by human occupants.

Bathroom. A room affording privacy containing bathing and sanitary facilities provided within each living unit consisting of a water closet, a tub or shower, and a lavatory basin.

Change of occupancy. Any circumstances wherein the composition of the residents of a dwelling unit changes either through the sale, lease, rental or other provision for the occupancy of any dwelling unit or by the addition of one or more persons to the number of residents of a dwelling unit, except by birth, assumed legal responsibility of minors or relatives of blood or marriage; provided however, in no event shall the relatives of blood or marriage be an exemption from the change of occupancy if such occupancy violates maximum space requirements.
 

Conditional occupancy permit. A document which states the names, ages, relationships and number of occupants of a dwelling unit which does not comply with all of the provisions of the Property Maintenance Code. It is issued only under specified circumstances listed in s e c t i o n 1 2 - 2 5 for a limited, specified length of time.

Debris. Unused or discarded items or portions of items of any type including furniture, play items, used building materials or fixtures, tools, appliances, equipment or machinery, containers, lumber, wood, rocks, bricks, broken concrete, metal or plastic items, vehicle parts, and any other material which has been placed or scattered on any lot, yard, open area, or underneath, or within a structure or part of a structure.

Deterioration. The condition or appearance of a building or part thereof, characterized by breaks, holes, rot, crumbling, peeling, rusting or other evidence of physical decay or neglect, excessive use, or lack of maintenance.

Family. One or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption, occupying a dwelling unit as an individual housekeeping organization, or two unrelated persons having a child or children related by blood, adoption or foster care relationship to both such persons, and/or the biological, adopted or foster children of either such individual. A family may include two additional persons not related by blood, marriage or adoption. Foster children, who are legal wards of the court, are construed as adopted children for purposes of enumeration.

Flush water closet. A toilet bowl flushed with water under pressure with a water sealed trap above the floor level.

Gutter. A trough under an eave to carry off water.

Harborage. Any place where insects, pests or rodents can live, nest or seek shelter.

Kitchen. Any room containing any or all of the following equipment, or any area of a room within three feet of such equipment, sink or other devices for dish washing, stove or other device for cool storage of food, cabinets or shelves for storage of equipment and utensils, and counter or table for food preparation.

Maximum occupancy. The maximum number of persons permitted to reside in a dwelling unit.

Open storage. Storage of any items outside any residential structure, but not including lawn furniture, water hoses, lawn sprinklers, outdoor cooking equipment, or firewood that is intended for use by the occupant of the premises that is cut for use and stacked in an orderly manner at least 12 inches off the ground and stored behind the front building line.

Plumbing. Facilities and equipment including, but not limited to, the following: gas pipes, gas burning equipment, water pipes, steam pipes, garbage disposal units, waste pipes, toilets, sinks, installed dishwashers, lavatories, bathtubs, shower baths, installed clothes washing machines, catch basins, drains, vents and any other similar fixtures, together with all connections to water, sewer, vent or gas lines.

Privacy. The existence of conditions which will permit a person or persons to carry out an activity without interruption or interference either by sight or sound, by unwanted persons.

Rental property. (1) Any dwelling or part of any dwelling for the use of which money is paid by someone; or (2) any occupied dwelling that is not occupied by the owner.

Renter. (1) Any person, other than the owner, occupying a dwelling unit for the use of which money is paid; or (2) any person occupying a dwelling that is not occupied by the owner.

Repair. To restore to a sound and acceptable state of operation, serviceability or appearance. Repairs shall be expected to last approximately as long as would the replacement by new items.

Replace. To remove an existing item or portion of a system and to construct or install a new item of similar or improved quality as the existing item when new. Replacement will ordinarily take place when the item is beyond repair.

Rodent extermination. Extermination by methods approved by the St. Louis County Health Department, and shall include removal of any condition which may provide food, shelter or protection for rats, thus favoring their existence or multiplication, and the closing of all openings in exterior walls at the ground and first floor levels.

Rodent harborage. Any condition which may provide food, shelter or protection for rats, thus favoring their existence or multiplication.

Rubbish container. A watertight container with tightfitting lid for the temporary storage of garbage and rubbish that is constructed of metal, or other durable material impervious to rodents, that is capable of being serviced without creating unsanitary conditions.

Space heater. A self-contained heating appliance of either the circulating type or the radiant type and intended primarily to heat only one room.

Substandard. All dwellings which do not conform to the minimum standards established by this Property Maintenance Code or of the city's Code of Ordinances.

Yard. An open space at grade on the same lot as a building or structure located between the main building and the adjoining lot line, and/or street line. The measurement of a yard shall be the minimum horizontal distance between the lot line and the building structure.
 

Amended to insert Section 301.4 Lead-based paint. Interior and exterior painted surfaces of dwellings and child and day care facilities, including fences and out buildings, which contain in excess of 0.06 percent lead by weight shall be removed or covered in an approved manner.

Amended to insert Section 302.1.1 Domestic animals. The occupant shall maintain the exterior property free of the excrement of the occupant's domestic animals by removal with reasonable frequency.

Section 302.4 Weeds. Insert: 12 inches (304.8 mm).

Amended to insert Section 302.4.1 Trees. All exterior property areas shall be maintained free of dead, diseased or dangerous trees, and dead, diseased or dangerous tree limbs. Such trees which are located on single or two-family residential properties shall be removed to ground level. Such trees which are located on multifamily or commercial properties shall be removed to ground level, and the remaining stump shall be ground to a level of tree (3) inches (76 mm) below grade.

Amended to insert Section 302.4.2 Landscape materials. All lawn areas and landscaping shall be maintained on a continual basis. All plant materials specified in screening and landscape plans required under Appendix A—Zoning of the Maplewood Code of Ordinances that are dead or diseased shall be replaced in conformity with the approved plan with identical or like species in the size required by the plan.

Amended to insert Section 302.10 Open storage. All exterior property and premises shall be maintained free of open storage.

Section 304.13.1 Glazing is hereby amended to read as follows: All glazing materials shall be maintained in a safe condition, and free of cracks longer than one and a half (1.5) inches.

Section 304.14 Insect screens. Insert: April 15, November 15.

Amended to insert Section 304.15.1 Garages and storage structures. All garages and storage structures shall be provided with operable doors.
