The nature of the permit desired, as to collect, transport, process, or dispose of solid waste of any combination thereof; The characteristics of solid waste to be collected, transported, processed, disposed;
The number of solid waste transportation vehicles to be operated thereunder;

The precise location or locations of solid waste processing or disposal facilities to be used; Boundaries of the collection area;
Evidence of a current state vehicle safety inspection;

Evidence of a current sanitation inspection by the county department of community health and medical care; and

Such other information as required by the city clerk including evidence of compliance with the workmen's compensation laws of the state.
 

(f)



(g)





(h)







(i)



(j)



(k)


(l)
 

Issuance. If the application shows that the applicant will collect, transport, process or dispose of solid wastes without hazard to the public health or the environment and in conformity with the laws of the state and this section, the city clerk shall issue the permit authorized by this section. The per be issued for a period of one year.
Renewal. The annual collection permit may be renewed upon payment of the fee as designated herein if the business has not been modified and if the inspections required in subsection (e) of this section are current and if the insurance required in subsection (d) of this section remains in force. If modifications have been made, the applicant shall reapply for a permit as set forth in this section. No permits authorized by this section shall be transferable from person to person.
Inspections. In order to ensure compliance with this section and the rules and regulations authorized herein, the city clerk is authorized to inspect all phases of solid waste management within the city. No inspection shall be made within any residential unit unless authorized by the occupant or by due process of law. In all instances where such inspections reveal violation of this section, the rules and regulations authorized herein for the storage, collection, transportation, processing or disposal of solid waste or the laws of the state, the director shall issue notice for each such violation stating therein the violation or violations found, the time and date and the corrective measure to be taken, together with the time in which such corrections shall be made.
Suspension or revocation. In all cases, when the corrective measures have not been taken within the time specified, the city clerk shall suspended or revoke the permit or permits involved in the violation; however, in those cases where an extension of time will permit correction and there is no public health hazard treated by the delay, one extension of time not to exceed the original time period may be given.
Appeals. Any person who feels aggrieved by any notice of violation or order issued pursuant thereto of the city clerk may within ten days of the act for which redress is sought appeal directly to the mayor and city council in writing, setting forth in a concise statement the act being appealed and the grounds for its reversal.
Vehicles to display stickers. All collection vehicles operating under any permit required by this section shall display the required license sticker on the windshield.
Temporary use of vehicles lacking stickers. Temporary use of vehicles lacking a license sticker shall have prior approval of the city clerk.
 

(Code 1982, § 18-268; Ord. No. 4491, § 10, 4-23-1991)

ARTICLE XII. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY



Sec. 14-670. - Deinitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Taxicab means a motor vehicle offered to the public by a taxicab business, performing a bona fide for hire taxicab service, having a capacity of not more than five passengers, exclusive of the driver, and not operated on a regular route or between fixed termini.

Taxicab business means the business of offering to the public motor vehicular transportation for a charge on other than fixed routes. (Code 1982, § 18-255; Ord. No. 4491, § 9, 4-23-1991)

Sec. 14-671. - Business license—Required.

No person shall engage in or operate a taxicab business in the city unless he has a valid license. (Code 1982, § 18-256; Ord. No. 4491, § 9, 4-23-1991)

Sec. 14-672. - Same—Application; contents.

(2)

(3)

(4)

(5)
 
The applicant's full name and home address; if a partnership, the full name and home address of each partner; if a corporation, the full name and home address of each officer and director;
The trade name under which the applicant is to do business; The address of the applicant's principal place of business; The number of taxicabs actually owned by the applicant;
The number of taxicabs held under lease by the applicant;
 

(6)

(7)

The make, model, motor number and serial number and registered owner of each taxicab; The applicant's experience in the taxicab business;
The schedule of rates to be charged.
 

(Code 1982, § 18-257; Ord. No. 4491, § 9, 4-23-1991)

Sec. 14-703. - Metropolitan taxicab commission—Authority to license and regulate vehicles for hire.

The regional taxicab commission, also known as the metropolitan taxicab commission, as established by RSMo 67.1804, is empowered to regulate vehicles for hire in the county. The metropolitan taxicab commission has adopted a vehicles for hire code and regulates such vehicles through administration of its code.

(Code 1982, § 18-258; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-704. - Code adopted.

The vehicles for hire code of the metropolitan taxicab commission is hereby adopted as the vehicles for hire code of the city and incorporated herein by reference.

(Code 1982, § 18-259; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-705. - City clerk to maintain copy of vehicles for hire code.

The city clerk shall maintain a current copy of the vehicles for hire code on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1982, § 18-260; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)

Sec. 14-706. - Duty to comply.

Any person owning or operating a vehicle regulated by the vehicles for hire code, and other persons subject to the regulations of the code, shall comply with the regulations of the metropolitan taxicab commission and the lawful direction of its agents.

(Code 1982, § 18-261; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-707. - Police authorized to enforce regulations of the metropolitan taxicab commission.

The police department is authorized to enforce the regulations of the Metropolitan Taxicab Commission Vehicles for Hire Code. The police department shall assist agents of the metropolitan taxicab commission in enforcement of the provisions of the code within the city.

(Code 1982, § 18-262; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-708. - Business license issuance.

(1)

(2)

(Code 1982, § 18-263; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-709. - Commission's enforcement action afects city license.

Any administrative action or judgment by the metropolitan taxicab commission for violation of the Metropolitan Taxicab Commission Vehicles for Hire Code which suspends or revokes an operating license shall simultaneously suspend or revoke the license issued by the city.

(Code 1982, § 18-264; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)


Sec. 14-710. - License revocation.

The license issued by the city clerk shall be subject to revocation in accordance with the regulations set forth in article II, division 2 of this chapter.
 

(Code 1982, § 18-265; Ord. No. 5393, § I, 3-13-2007)

ARTICLE - XIII.

SHORT TERM VACATION



Sec. 14-800. - Purpose.

 
(a)



(b)
 
The purpose of this article is to establish regulations for short term vacation rentals in order to safeguard the peace, safety and general welfare of neighborhoods within the City of Maplewood by minimizing negative secondary affects related to short term vacation rentals including excessive noise, disorderly conduct, illegal parking, overcrowding, and excessive accumulation of refuse.
This article is not intended to provide any owner of residential property with the right or privilege to violate any deed restriction or private conditions, governance or restrictions applicable to the property's owner that may prohibit the use of such owner's residential property for short term vacation rentals as defined in this article. Short term vacation rentals are not permitted in dwelling units that have deed restrictions for affordable housing purposes or other city imposed conditions of approval or restrictions would prohibit the use of such dwelling as a short term vacation rental as defined herein.
 
(Ord. No. 5785, § I, 10-13-2015)


Sec. 14-801. - Deinitions.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)



(d)

(e)
 
Owner means the person or entity that holds legal and equitable title to a short term vacation rental property and who resides there as the legal residence of such person.
Owner occupied means the owner (or person controlling any entity that is the owner) resides in said short term vacation rental property as the owner's (or such controlling person's) legal residence.
Short term vacation rental means a rental of any legally permitted dwelling unit, or a portion of such a legally permitted dwelling unit, located in a single family zoning district as defined by sections 5 6 - 7 1 to 5 6 - 7 3 of this Code for a period of less than 30 consecutive calendar days, in compliance with the terms of this article sections 1 4 - 8 0 0 to 1 4 - 8 0 4 .
Short term vacation rental property means the property in which a short term vacation rental is located.

Transient means any person who occupies any rooms or accommodations within a short term vacation rental property for a period of less than 30 continuous days.
 
(Ord. No. 5785, § I, 10-13-2015)


Sec. 14-802. - Short term vacation rentals.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)


(d)

(e)


(f)

(g)
 
Short term vacation rentals shall be permitted only in owner occupied single family residences within the SR Single-family Residential Zoning District and as permitted as provided in the zoning ordinance.
Short term vacation rentals shall be subject to and shall comply with all requirements of the city and state building, fire, safety and occupancy codes and limits.
The owner of the short term vacation rental shall spend the night on-site at the short term vacation rental property at all times during the term of any short term vacation rental.
Not more than two rooms in any dwelling unit may be rented at the same time as a short term vacation rental.

The owner of any short term vacation rental shall be required to apply for and obtain a short term vacation rental permit and business license from the city before renting or advertising the availability of the short term vacation rental.
A short term vacation rental permit shall be valid from July 1 and shall expire on the following June 30.

Obtaining and renewing a short term vacation rental permit. The owner of the short term vacation rental property shall adhere to the following conditions and shall submit the following information on a short term vacation rental permit application form provided by the city, which shall include, at a minimum, the following information:
 
(1)

(2)
 
The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the short term vacation rental property.

Such other information as the city manager or designee deems reasonably necessary to administer this article.
 

(h)


(i)
 

Any false statements or false information provided in the application for a short term vacation rental permit shall be grounds for denial of permit, permit revocation or imposition of penalties as outlined in this Code of Ordinances.
A short term vacation rental permit application shall be denied if the owner has had a short term vacation rental permit revoked within the past 12 months for the same or other short term vacation rental property. If a short term vacation rental permit is revoked twice, no short term
 

vacation rental permit shall subsequently be issued for such owner or such short term vacation rental property.
 

(j)



(k)



(l)





(m)







(n)



(o)


(p)
 

Operational requirement. The owner shall use reasonable, prudent business practices to insure that the short term vacation rental property is used in a manner that complies with all applicable laws, rules and regulations pertaining to the use and occupancy of the short term vacation rental property.
The name, address and telephone number of a local contact person who shall be available 24 hours per day, seven days per week, for the purpose of responding within 45 minutes to complaints regarding the condition, operation or conduct of occupants of the short term vacation rental unit or their guests, shall at all times be kept on file with the city.
The owner shall post the short term vacation rental permit on the exterior of the short term vacation rental property within plain view for the general public with a 24 hours a day, seven days a week local contact phone number for complaints. The permit shall be between eight and one- half inches by 11 inches and four inches by five inches in size and shall be displayed at all times that the short term vacation rental property is being used for a short term vacation rental.
The owner or local contact shall upon notification that any transient, occupant or guest of the short term vacation rental property has created unreasonable noise or disturbances, engaged in disorderly conduct or committed violation of any applicable law, rule or regulations pertaining to the use and occupancy of the short term vacation rental property, respond in a timely and appropriate manner to immediately halt or prevent reoccurrence of such conduct. Failure of the owner or local contact to respond to such calls or complaints regarding the condition, operation or conduct of the occupants and/or guests of a short term vacation rental in a timely and appropriate manner shall be grounds for revocation of the short term vacation rental permit and shall subject the owner to all administrative, legal and equitable remedies available to the city.
The owner or local contact shall use reasonably prudent business practices to insure that the occupants and/or guests of the short term rental unit do not create unreasonable noise or disturbances, engage in disorderly conduct or violate any applicable law, rule or regulation pertaining to the use and occupancy of the subject short term vacation rental property.
No amplified or reproduced sound shall be used outside or audible from the property line of any short term vacation rental property between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.
Prior to rental of a short term vacation rental property, the owner shall:
 

(1)


(2)



(3)



(4)

(5)


(6)
 

Obtain the contact information of all transients, including the name, permanent address, telephone number and emergency contract for each person to occupy the short term rental vacation property.
Require the transient to execute a formal acknowledgement that he or she is legally responsible for compliance by all occupants or guests of the short term vacation rental unit with all applicable laws, rules and regulations pertaining to the use and occupancy of the short term vacation rental unit.
Information required in items (1) and (2) above shall be maintained by the owner for a period of three years and shall be made available upon request to any officer of the city responsible for the enforcement of any provision of the municipal code or any applicable law, rule or regulation pertaining to the use and occupancy of the short term vacation rental property.
On-site parking shall be allowed on approved driveway, garage and/or carport areas only.

The number of occupants allowed to occupy any short term vacation rental property shall be limited to two people per bedroom and no more than two bedrooms within any short term vacation rental property shall be rented at the same time.
The city manager or designee shall have the authority to impose additional conditions on the use of any short term vacation rental property to insure that any potential secondary affects unique to the subject short term vacation rental unit are avoided or adequately mitigated.
 
(q)
 
The owner shall post the current short term vacation rental permit number on or in any advertisement appearing in any written publication or any website that promotes the availability or existence of a short term vacation rental property.
 
(Ord. No. 5785, § I, 10-13-2015)


Sec. 14-803. - Permit procedure.

 
(a)


(b)
 
Upon receiving an application for a permit for a short term vacation rental property that complies with the provisions of this article, the residents within 200 feet of the property lines of the subject property shall be notified of the application for short term vacation rental permit.
The fee for a short term vacation rental permit shall be $75.00 annually.
 

(Ord. No. 5785, § I, 10-13-2015)


Sec. 14-804. - Penalties and enforcement.

 
(a)



(b)


(c)
 
Upon request by the city manager or designee, owners shall provide access to the short term vacation rental property and to any records related to the use and occupancy of the short term vacation rental property during normal business hours for the purpose of determining compliance with this article.
Any person violating any of the provisions in this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor punishable pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 , general penalty; continuing violations.
In addition to any penalty imposed pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 of this Code, the city manager or his designee may impose additional conditions on
 

the use of any short term vacation rental permit pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 4 - 8 0 2 (p)(6), permits.
 

(d)



(e)
 

Except as otherwise expressly provided in sections 1 4 - 8 0 0 to 1 4 - 8 0 4 , enforcement of sections 1 4 - 8 0 0 to 1 4 - 8 0 4 is at the sole discretion of the city. Nothing in this article shall create a right of action on any person against the city or its agents for damages or to compel public enforcement of the provisions of sections 1 4 - 8 0 0 and 1 4 - 8 0 4 against private parties.
Pursuant to s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 (c) of this Code, each and every day during any portion of which a violation of this Code or any other ordinance of this city is committed, continued or permitted, shall be a separate offense.
 
(Ord. No. 5785, § I, 10-13-2015)


Chapter 16 - COURTS



Sec. 16-1. - Established.

There is hereby established in this city a municipal court, to be known as the "Maplewood Municipal Court, a division of the Twenty-First Judicial Circuit of the State of Missouri." This court is a continuation of the municipal court of the city as previously established, and is termed herein "the municipal court."

(Code 1972, § 205.01; Code 1982, § 20-1; Ord. No. 3965, § 1, 12-11-1978)


Sec. 16-2. - Proceedings; trial by jury.

 
(a)

(b)



(c)



(d)
 
All cases brought before the municipal court shall be entitled "City of Maplewood against (name of person charged)."

The docket shall show the name of the complainant, the nature of the offense, the date of trial, the names of the witnesses sworn and examined, the finding of the court or jury, the judgment and penalties, if any, the date of payment or commitment, and such other information as will show the full proceedings in the case.
The charges shall be in writing and shall set forth the violations complained of and the section of the Charter or ordinance that was violated. It shall conclude with the phrase "against the peace and dignity of the city." There may be two or more counts. The charges shall be sworn to by the city attorney or any other person verifying or making the complaint before a warrant shall issue.
Any person charged with a violation of the Charter or ordinances shall be entitled to a trial by jury to the extent jury trial are permitted or required in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge.
 
(Code 1972, § 205.02; Code 1982, § 20-2; Ord. No. 3965, § 2, 12-11-1978)


Sec. 16-3. - Court costs; fling fees.

 
(a)
 
In addition to any fine that may be imposed by the municipal judge there shall be assessed as costs in all cases the following:
 

(1)

(2)

(3)



(4)





(5)
 

General costs, in the amount of $12.00.

In all cases, costs for the training of police officers, in the amount of $2.00 to be transmitted to the city treasurer.

In all cases, costs in the amount of $1.00 to be deposited with the treasurer of the state in the Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission Fund, to be used statewide for training of peace officers. The $1.00 surcharge assessed pursuant to this subsection shall be in addition to the $2.00 surcharge assessed pursuant to subsection (a)(2) of this section.
A surcharge of $2.00 pursuant to the provisions of RSMo 488.5026 shall be collected in all cases, except where the proceeding is dismissed by the court or where the costs are to be paid by the city. All funds collected pursuant to this subsection shall be used only to develop and maintain a biometric verification system to ensure that inmates are properly identified and tracked within a local jail system and to pay for any expenses related to custody, housing and other expenses for inmates.
In addition to any other costs or fees provided in this Code pertaining to cases filed in the Maplewood Municipal Division, an additional sum of $5.00 shall be assessed as costs in each proceeding filed in the Maplewood Municipal Division for violation of ordinances of the city, provided that no such fee shall be collected for nonmoving traffic violations or in any proceedings when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court. All sums collected pursuant to this section shall be distributed as follows:
 
a.	Ninety-five percent of such fees shall be paid to the director of revenue of the state for deposit to the Crime Victim's Compensation Fund and the services to the victim's fund as provided in RSMo 595.045.
b.	Five percent shall be paid to the city treasury.
 

(6)





(7)
 

In addition to any other costs or fees provided in this Code pertaining to cases filed in Maplewood Municipal Division, an additional sum of
$1.00 shall be assessed as costs in each proceeding filed in the Maplewood Municipal Division for the violation of the ordinances of this city. All sums collected pursuant to this subsection shall be distributed on a monthly basis to the county to be used only for the purposes of providing operating expenses for shelters for battered persons as provided in RSMo 488.607.
Other costs, such as service costs and witness fees, in the same amounts as provided before the associate circuit judge in criminal prosecutions.
 

(8)

(9)
 

Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for apprehension or confinement in the county jail.

Mileage, in tile same amount as provided to the sheriff in criminal violations, for each mile and fraction thereof the officer must travel (both directions) in order to serve any warrant or commitment or order of this court.
 
(b)
 
The costs of any action may be assessed against the prosecuting witness and judgment be rendered against him that he pay the same and stand committed until paid in any case where it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was commenced without probable cause and from malicious motives.
 
(Code 1972, § 205.04; Code 1982, § 20-3; Ord. No. 3965, § 3, 12-11-1978; Ord. No. 4063, § 1, 10-14-1980; Ord. No. 4693, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 4761, § 1, 12-10-
1996; Ord. No. 5476, § 6-10-2008)


Sec. 16-4. - Selection of judges.

The judge of the city's municipal court shall be known as a municipal judge of the Twenty-First Judicial Circuit, and shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the majority of the council. When necessary, a provisional judge may be appointed in the same manner as the municipal judge.

(Code 1972, § 205.05; Code 1982, § 20-4; Ord. No. 3965, § 4, 12-11-1978)


Sec. 16-5. - Public defender.

There is hereby established the office of public defender of the municipal court. The public defender shall be a lawyer licensed to practice by the state, a resident of the county, and shall be appointed by the municipal judge. His compensation for his duties shall be set by the municipal judge and approved by the council. The duties of the public defender shall be to serve as counsel when appointed by the municipal judge or the special judge of the city to represent persons appearing before the municipal court and accused of a violation of this Code of which subjects them to the possibility of imprisonment, and which parties demonstrate to the satisfaction of the municipal judge, or the special judge, that they are unable to employ counsel on their own behalf and desire to have counsel appointed to represent them.

(Code 1972, § 203.04A; Code 1982, § 20-5; Ord. No. 3716, § 1, 11-27-1972)


Sec. 16-6. - Search warrants.

 
(a)





(b)


(c)
 
The municipal judge shall have the authority to issue search warrants, to the fullest extent permitted by the laws of the state, for searches or inspections to determine the existence, evidence or fruits of violations of any of the ordinances of the city, and to seize, photograph, copy or record property, articles, materials and substances, and to search for and seize persons, of the kinds authorized to be searched for and seized pursuant to the laws of this state, including, but not limited to, RSMo 542.271.
All warrants issued by the municipal judge shall be directed to the chief of police or any other police officer of the city. The warrants shall be executed by the chief of police or any other police officer of the city at any place within the limits of the city.
Warrants and searches or inspections and seizures made pursuant thereto shall conform to and be governed by the following provisions:
 

(1)

(2)
 

The chief of police, any police officer, or the prosecuting attorney of the city may make application for the issuance of a search warrants. The application shall:
 
a.	Be in writing;

b.	State the time and date of the making of the application;

c.	Identify the property or places to be searched in sufficient detail and particularity that the officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it;
d.	State facts sufficient to show probable cause for the issuance of a search warrant to search for violations of any chapter, provision or provisions of this Code specified in the application;
e.	Be verified by the oath or affirmation of the applicant; and

f.	Be filed with the clerk of the municipal court.
 

(3)



(4)





(5)

(6)
 

The application shall be supplemented by written affidavits verified by oath or affirmation. Such affidavits shall be considered in determining whether there is probable cause for the issuance of a search warrant and in filling out any deficiencies in the description of the property or place to be searched. Oral testimony shall not be considered.
The judge shall hold a nonadversary hearing to determine whether sufficient facts have been stated to justify the issuance of a search warrant. If it appears from the application and any supporting affidavits that there is probable cause to inspect or search for violations of any specified chapter, provision or provisions of this Code, a search warrant shall be issued immediately to search for such violations. The warrant shall be issued in the form of an original and two copies.
The application and any supporting affidavits and a copy of the warrants shall be retained in the records of the municipal court. The search warrant shall:
 
a.	Be in writing and in the name of the issuing authority;
 

b.	Be directed to the chief of police or any other police officer of the city;

c.	State the time and date the warrant is issued;

d.	Identify the property or places to be searched in sufficient detail and particularity that the officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it;
e.	Command that the described property, articles, materials, substances, or persons found thereon or therein be seized or photographed or copied and returned, or the photograph or copy be brought, within ten days after filing of the application, to the judge who issued the warrant, to be dealt with according to law; and
f.	Be signed by the municipal judge, with his title of office indicated.
 

(7)


(8)


(9)






(10)
 

A search warrant issued under this section may be executed only by the chief of police or a police officer of the city. The warrant shall be executed by conducting the search commanded.
A search warrant shall be executed as soon as practicable and shall expire if it is not executed and the return made within ten days after the making of such application.
After execution of the search warrant, the warrant, with a return thereon signed by the officer making the search, shall be delivered to the judge who issued the warrant. The return shall show the date and manner of execution, what if anything was seized, and the name of the possessor and of the owner of the property or place searched and of any property, articles, materials or substances seized, when not the same person, if known. The return shall be accompanied by a copy of the itemized receipt required by section RSMo 542.291 and subsection (c)(14) of this section, pertaining to any property, articles, materials or substances seized.
A search warrant shall be deemed invalid if:
 

a.	It was not issued by a judge of the municipal court;

b.	It was issued without a written application having been filed and verified;

c.	It was issued without probable cause;

d.	It was not issued with respect to property or places within the city;

e.	It does not describe the property or places to be searched with sufficient certainty;

f.	It was not signed by the judge who issued it; or

g.	It was not executed within the time prescribed by subsection (c)(8) of this section.
 

(11)

(12)


(13)


(14)


(15)
 

The search shall be conducted in a reasonable manner. The search may be made at night if making it during the daytime is not practicable. The chief of police or police officer making a search pursuant to an invalid warrant, the invalidity of which is not apparent on its face, may
use such force as he would be justified in using if the warrant were valid.

The chief of police or police officer making a search may summon as many persons as he deems necessary to assist him in executing the warrant. Such persons shall not be held liable as a result of the illegality of the search and seizure.
If any property is seized, the officer shall give to the person from whose possession it is taken, if he is present, a copy of the warrant and an itemized receipt of the property taken. If no such person is present, the officer shall leave the copy and the receipt at the site of the search.
A copy of the itemized receipt of any property taken shall be delivered to the office of the prosecuting attorney of the city within two working days of the search.
 
(d)
 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse entry or access to any unit, dwelling or structure to any person to whom a search warrant has been issued authorizing search or inspection of said unit, dwelling or structure pursuant to the provisions of this section. Violation of this subsection
(d)	shall be punished as provided in s e c t i o n 1 - 1 1 .
 

(Code 1982, § 20-6; Ord. No. 4743, § 1, 8-13-1996)

State of Missouri,

I,	, herewith state and declare that I reside at Number	Street, City of Maplewood, County of St. Louis, State of Missouri; that I am a qualified voter therein; that I am a candidate for nomination to the office of	of Maplewood to be voted upon at the  primary election to be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in February, 20	; and I hereby request that my name be printed upon the official primary ballot for the nomination by such election for such office.
 

(b)

(d)

Each petition shall be verified by one or more persons as to the qualifications and residence, with the street number of each of the persons so signing the petition, and the petition shall be substantially in the following form:
The undersigned, duly qualified electors of the City of Maplewood and residing at the places set opposite our respective names hereto, do hereby request that the name of	be placed on the ballot as a candidate for nomination for	at the primary election to be held in the city on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in February, 20	. The city clerk shall thereupon cause such ballots to be printed.
On the day following the primary election, the city clerk shall canvass the returns so received from all the polling precincts, and make and publish in two newspapers in the city, if there be two, at least once, the result thereof. The canvass by the city clerk shall be publicly made.
The two candidates having the highest number of votes for mayor shall be the candidates whose names shall be placed upon the ballot for
mayor at the next succeeding general municipal election, and the two candidates receiving the highest number of votes for each council seat shall be placed upon the ballot for councilman at such municipal election.
 
(Code 1972, § 204.02; Code 1982, § 9-1; Ord. No. 4853, § III, 10-27-1998)

(b)


(c)

(Code 1972, § 204.03; Code 1982, § 9-3)

Chapter 20 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL



Sec. 20-1. - Deinitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Chief executive officer means the city manager or other official appointed by the city council. (Code 1982, § 8-1)

Secs. 20-2—20-20. - Reserved.


ARTICLE II. - MAPLEWOOD EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY



Sec. 20-21. - Local organization—Establishment; purpose.

There is hereby created a local municipal organization for emergency management and disaster planning for the preparation and the carrying out of all the emergency functions other than functions for which the military forces are primarily responsible, to minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack in accordance with RSMo 44.080.

(Code 1982, § 8-2)


Sec. 20-22. - Composition.

The organization established by s e c t i o n 2 0 - 2 1 shall consist of a coordinator and other additional members to be selected by the director in order to conform to the state organization and procedures for the conduct of emergency operations as outlined in the state survival plan.

(Code 1982, § 8-3)


Sec. 20-23. - Coordinator appointed; responsibilities.

 
(a)
 
A coordinator of the municipal emergency management agency for the conduct of emergency operations shall be appointed by the manager, by
 

and with the advice and consent of the city council, and shall serve until removed by the same.
 

(b)
 

The coordinator shall have such responsibilities for the organization, administration and operation of this organization as is delegated by the chief executive officer subject to the direction and control of the city council, as provided by statute.
 
(Code 1982, § 8-4)


Sec. 20-24. - Functions of agency.

The municipal emergency management agency created by this chapter shall perform such emergency management and disaster planning functions within the municipality as shall be prescribed in and by the state emergency management plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual-aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by the RSMo c h . 4 4 or the state survival plan.

(Code 1982, § 8-5)


Sec. 20-25. - Appointment, etc., of personnel; mobile support units.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)
 
The coordinator of the municipal emergency management agency shall appoint, provide, without compensation, or remove any personnel needed by the organization for the proper function of its duties.
The coordinator shall form mobile support units as provided for in the RSMo c h . 4 4 and the state survival plan and shall designate the leaders thereof.
Any member of a mobile support team who is a municipal employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor, or the state director of civil defense, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office.
 
(Code 1982, § 8-6)


Sec. 20-26. - Oath of personnel.

Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the municipal civil defense organization shall, before entering upon his duties, take an oath, in writing, before a person authorized to administer oaths in the state, which shall be filed with the director, which oath shall be substantially as follows:

I,	, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Missouri, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservations or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter.
And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been, a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the municipal emergency management agency, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence.

(Code 1982, § 8-7)


Sec. 20-27. - Ofce space.

The city manager or city council is authorized to designate space in any municipally owned or leased building for the municipal emergency management agency as its office.

(Code 1982, § 8-8)


Sec. 20-28. - Mutual-aid agreements.

 
(a)





(b)
 
The chief executive officer of the city, with the approval of the governor, may enter into mutual-aid arrangements or agreements with other public and private agencies within and without the state for reciprocal emergency management and disaster planning. Such arrangements or
agreements shall be consistent with the state survival plan, and in time of emergency it shall be the duty of each local organization for emergency management and disaster planning to render assistance in accordance with the provisions of such mutual-aid arrangements or agreements.
The coordinator of the local organization for emergency management and disaster planning may assist in negotiation or reciprocal mutual-aid agreements between his organization and other public and private agencies and between the governor and the adjoining states or political subdivisions thereof, and shall carry out arrangements or agreements relating to the local unit.
 
(Code 1982, § 8-9)


Sec. 20-29. - Use of services, facilities, etc., of state ofces, agencies, etc.
 

In carrying out the emergency powers under the provisions of this chapter, the chief executive officer is directed to use the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the state and of the political subdivisions thereof, and the officers and personnel of all such departments, offices and agencies are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the governor and the state emergency management agency upon request.

(Code 1982, § 8-10)


Sec. 20-30. - Gifts, grants and loans.

Whenever the federal government or the state government, or any officer or agency thereof, shall offer to the state, or through the state to any political subdivision thereof, services, equipment, supplies, material or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of emergency management or disaster planning, the state acting through the governor, or the political subdivision, acting with the consent of the governor and through its executive officer, may accept such offer and upon acceptance the governor or executive officer of the political subdivision, as the case may be, to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the state or the political subdivisions subject to the terms of the offer.

(Code 1982, § 8-11)


Sec. 20-31. - Procurement of services, supplies, etc., in emergency.

In the event of an emergency as defined in the RSMo c h . 4 4 , the coordinator of the municipal emergency management agency is authorized, on behalf of the municipality, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to
the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as authorized by RSMo c h . 4 4 , provided that, if the city council meets at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body.

(Code 1982, § 8-12)


Sec. 20-32. - Certain statutory requirements may be waived in event of enemy attack.

In the event of enemy attack, the city manager or city council may waive any time consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by statute pertaining to the advertisement for bids for the performance of public work or entering into contracts.

(Code 1982, § 8-13)


Secs. 20-33—20-52. - Reserved.


ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCES


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY



Secs. 20-53—20-77. - Reserved.


DIVISION 2. - MUTUAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT



Sec. 20-78. - Contract with neighboring municipalities and districts.

The city hereby contracts respectively and separately with the cities of Brentwood, Clayton, Ladue, Richmond Heights, University City, and Shrewsbury, effective upon the passage and approval of a like ordinance by the legislative body of any of such cities or fire districts for the interchange of ambulance service of the fire departments of such cities, or fire districts, upon the conditions and provisions contained in this division.

(Code 1982, § 5-16; Ord. No. 3817, § 1, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-79. - Duty to respond to alarms.

The ambulance service of the city shall respond to emergency alarms on call from any part of the cities and fire districts referred to in s e c t i o n 2 0 - 7 8 , and the ambulance service of such cities and fire districts shall respond to emergency ambulance alarms on call in any part of the city, commencing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived and continuing indefinitely.

(Code 1982, § 5-17; Ord. No. 3817, § 2, 5-12-1975)
 

Sec. 20-80. - Termination of contract.

The contract set out in this division may be terminated at any time during its term by either party thereto upon passage of an ordinance to that effect by the legislative body thereof and upon serving on the city clerk of the other municipalities or fire districts a certified copy of such termination ordinance. The termination thereof shall take effect 60 days from the date of the service of such written notice.

(Code 1982, § 5-18; Ord. No. 3817, § 3, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-81. - Consideration.

The consideration for the service of the fire departments of each municipality and fire district, shall be the service given for the protection of the lives in the other municipalities and fire districts by the service of the other cities or fire districts hereto, and no compensation shall accrue or be paid to any of such cities or fire districts for the service of the ambulance service of the other cities or fire districts.

(Code 1982, § 5-19; Ord. No. 3817, § 4, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-82. - Liability to other participants.

No municipality or fire district through the contract set out in this division shall be liable to the other for failure to respond to any call by the other, or for delay or negligence or mistake in receiving and responding to any call, nor shall this contract be interpreted as being an agreement for the benefit for any third person.

(Code 1982, § 5-20; Ord. No. 3817, § 5, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-83. - Liability to employees.

Neither the city nor any other of the municipalities or fire districts referred to in s e c t i o n 2 0 - 7 8 shall be liable by reason of the contract set out in this division to any ambulance personnel, firefighter, official or employee of the other, nor shall any ambulance personnel, firefighter, official or employee of any of the parties to the contract set out in this division be considered for any purpose an ambulance personnel, firefighter, official or employee of any municipality or fire district other than the one by which he is regularly employed.

(Code 1982, § 5-21; Ord. No. 3817, § 6, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-84. - Damage to equipment or property to be borne by owner.

In case of loss or damage to the equipment or property of any of the municipalities or fire districts referred to in s e c t i o n 2 0 - 7 8 while responding to emergency ambulance alarms or at an emergency alarm or returning therefrom, such loss or damage shall be borne by the city or fire district owning such equipment or property.

(Code 1982, § 5-22; Ord. No. 3817, § 7, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-85. - Status of department while in another municipality or district.

Except as otherwise provided for in this division, when the fire department of a municipality or fire district referred to in s e c t i o n 2 0 - 7 8 responds to an emergency ambulance alarm in other municipalities or fire protection districts, it shall, during the time that its equipment and personnel are in such municipalities or fire protection districts, have the same status and be subject to and protected by all of the laws and ordinances of such municipalities and fire protection districts that have application to such municipalities and fire protection districts.

(Code 1982, § 5-23; Ord. No. 3817, § 8, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-86. - Minimum personnel and standards.

Each municipality and fire protection district referred to in s e c t i o n 2 0 - 7 8 shall maintain at least two qualified personnel on the ambulance unit when responding on an assist call. The driver/attendant and unit shall comply with all state laws that pertain to emergency ambulance services.

(Code 1982, § 5-24; Ord. No. 3817, § 10, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-87. - Determination of hospital to be used.

Hospitals to which patients are to be conveyed shall be at the discretion of the responding municipality or fire protection district and their policy shall be enforced.

(Code 1982, § 5-25; Ord. No. 3817, § 11, 5-12-1975)
 

Sec. 20-88. - Efect of contracting with other municipalities or districts.

In the event the cities of Brentwood, Clayton, Ladue, Richmond Heights, University City, or Shrewsbury should hereafter make a contract with any city or fire district other than the above enumerated cities and fire districts to furnish ambulance service for such cities and fire districts in exchange for compensation, such agreement shall automatically terminate the provisions of this division as to such membership city or fire district which shall hereafter so contract some third party or unincorporated area unless this member city shall have first received the approval of all the cities hereinabove enumerated in writing prior to executing such contractual agreement for the furnishing of services of the fire department.

(Code 1982, § 5-26; Ord. No. 3817, § 12, 5-12-1975)


Sec. 20-89. - City to furnish aid in event of disaster in county.

In the event of a natural or manmade disaster in any city or fire district within the county, the city further agrees to furnish ambulance service to the disaster without regard to all prior contractual agreements.

(Code 1982, § 5-27; Ord. No. 3817, § 13, 5-12-1975)

ARTICLE III. - FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT ORDINANCE



Sec. 22-42. - Statutory authorization, fndings of fact, and purposes.

 
(a)



(b)
 
Statutory authorization. The legislature of the State of Missouri has in RSMo 89.020 delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt floodplain management regulations designed to protect the health, safety, and general welfare. Therefore, the city council of the City of Maplewood, Missouri ordains as follows:
Findings of fact.
 

(1)





(2)



(3)
 

Flood losses resulting from periodic inundation. The special flood hazard areas of the City of Maplewood, Missouri are subject to inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary
public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base; all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare.
General causes of the flood losses. These flood losses are caused by (1) the cumulative effect of development in any delineated floodplain causing increases in flood heights and velocities; and (2) the occupancy of flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods, hazardous to others, inadequately elevated, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages.
Methods used to analyze flood hazards. The flood insurance study (FIS) that is the basis of this article uses a standard engineering method of analyzing flood hazards which consist of a series of interrelated steps.
 
a.	Selection of a base flood that is based upon engineering calculations which permit a consideration of such flood factors as its expected frequency of occurrence, the area inundated, and the depth of inundation. The base flood selected for this article is representative of large floods which are characteristic of what can be expected to occur on the particular streams subject to this article. It is in the
 

general order of a flood which could be expected to have a one percent chance of occurrence in any one year as delineated on the Federal Insurance Administrator's FIS, and illustrative materials for St. Louis County dated February 4, 2015, as amended, and any future revisions thereto.
b.	Calculation of water surface profiles are based on a standard hydraulic engineering analysis of the capacity of the stream channel and overbank areas to convey the regulatory flood.
c.	Computation of a floodway required to convey this flood without increasing flood heights more than one foot at any point.

d.	Delineation of floodway encroachment lines within which no development is permitted that would cause any increase in flood height.

e.	Delineation of flood fringe, i.e., that area outside the floodway encroachment lines, but still subject to inundation by the base flood.
 

(c)
 

Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare; to minimize those losses described in subsection (b)(1) of this section; to establish or maintain the community's eligibility for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) as defined in 4 4 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 59.22(a) (3); and to meet the requirements of 4 4 CFR 60.3(d) by applying the provisions of this article to:
 
(1)


(2)


(3)
 
Restrict or prohibit uses that are dangerous to health, safety, or property in times of flooding or cause undue increases in flood heights or velocities;
Require uses vulnerable to floods, including public facilities that serve such uses, be provided with flood protection at the time of initial construction; and
Protect individuals from buying lands that are unsuited for the intended development purposes due to the flood hazard.
 

(Ord. No. 5759, § I, 1-13-2015)


Sec. 22-43. - General provisions.

 
(a)







(b)


(c)


(d)



(e)


(f)







(g)
 
Lands to which ordinance applies. This article shall apply to all lands within the jurisdiction of the City of Maplewood, Missouri identified as numbered and unnumbered A zones and AE zones, on the flood insurance rate maps (FIRMs) for St. Louis County on map panels, 29189C0327K and 29189C0331K dated February 4, 2015, as amended, and any future revisions thereto. In all areas covered by this article, no development shall be permitted except through the issuance of a floodplain development permit, granted by the city council or its duly designated representative under such safeguards and restrictions as the city council or the designated representative may reasonably impose for the promotion and maintenance of the general welfare, health of the inhabitants of the community, and as specifically noted in.
Floodplain administrator. The director of public works or his designated representative is hereby designated as the floodplain administrator under this article.
Compliance. No development located within the special flood hazard areas of this community shall be located, extended, converted, or structurally altered without full compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable regulations.
Abrogation and greater restrictions. It is not intended by this article to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this article imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this article shall prevail. All other ordinances inconsistent with this article are hereby repealed to the extent of the inconsistency only.
Interpretation . In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be held to be minimum requirements, shall be liberally construed in favor of the governing body, and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers granted by state statutes.
Warning and disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur on rare occasions or the flood heights may be increased by man- made or natural causes, such as ice jams and bridge openings restricted by debris. This ordinance does not imply that areas outside the floodway and flood fringe or land uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damage. This ordinance shall not create a liability on the part of the City of Maplewood, any officer or employee thereof, for any flood damages that may result from reliance on this article or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder.
Severability. If any section, clause, provision, or portion of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of appropriate jurisdiction, the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby.
 
(Ord. No. 5759, § I, 1-13-2015)


Sec. 22-44. - Administration.

 
(a)

Floodplain development permit required. A floodplain development permit shall be required for all proposed construction or other development, including the placement of manufactured homes, in the areas described in s e c t i o n 2 2 - 4 5 . No person, firm, corporation, or unit of government shall initiate any development or substantial-improvement or cause the same to be done without first obtaining a separate floodplain development permit for each structure or other development.
Designation of floodplain administrator. The director of public works or his designated representative is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this article.
Duties and responsibilities of floodplain administrator. duties of the director of public works or his designated representative shall include, but
 

not be limited to:
 

(1)


(2)

Review of all applications for floodplain development permits for proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been obtained from federal, state, or local governmental agencies from which prior approval is required by federal, state, or local law;
Review all subdivision proposals and other proposed new development, including manufactured home parks or subdivisions, to determine whether such proposals will be reasonably safe from flooding;
Issue floodplain development permits for all approved applications;

Notify adjacent communities and the Missouri State Emergency Management Agency (Mo SEMA) prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse, and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA);
Assure that the flood carrying capacity is not diminished and shall be maintained within the altered or relocated portion of any watercourse. Verify and maintain a record of the actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or
substantially improved structures;

Verify and maintain a record of the actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) that the new or substantially improved non-residential structures have been floodproofed;
When floodproofing techniques are utilized for a particular non-residential structure, the director of public works or his designated representative shall require certification from a registered professional engineer or architect.
