ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT



Sec. 24-52. - Chief to have command.

The chief of the fire department shall have command of the firefighters of the city and shall be responsible for the efficiency and training of the members and employees of the fire department.

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(A); Code 1982, § 11-31)


Sec. 24-53. - Chief's powers and duties.

The chief of the fire department shall:

 
(1)
 
Make or cause to be made frequent inspections of all fire hydrants within the city and see that they are at all times in good working order and ready for use.
 

(2)


(3)

(4)

(5)


(6)
 

Inspect all engines, hoses, hose carriages, hook and ladder apparatus and trucks and all other equipment and property of or connected with th department, to see that it is properly cared for and ready for immediate use.
Have general custody of all property under the control of the fire department. Where possible, attend all fires and direct the work of the firefighters.
Have power to cause the removal of any building, fence or structure of any kind for the purpose of checking the progress of any fire and, in an emergency, he may use explosives to demolish buildings or other structures, in order to check the spread of fire.
Have authority to prescribe the limits in the vicinity of a fire within which no person other than residents therein, city councilmembers or persons admitted by order of an officer of the police department, is permitted.
 

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(B); Code 1982, § 11-32)


Sec. 24-54. - Promulgation of rules of conduct for department members.

The chief of the fire department shall promulgate, by written order, rules for the conduct of the members of the department and for the performance of their duties. Disobedience to such rules shall be grounds for dismissal from the department as provided in c h a p t e r 3 8 .

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(F); Code 1982, § 11-33)


Sec. 24-55. - Promulgation of regulations for ambulances.

The chief of the fire department shall promulgate, by written order, regulations governing the policy of fire department operations of the city ambulance. (Code 1972, § 203A.01(A)(1); Code 1982, § 11-34; Ord. No. 3844, § 1, 2-23-1976)

Sec. 24-56. - Fireighters to obey orders of oicers.

Every firefighter shall obey every order of the officers of the fire department, and upon every failure to do so, the firefighters may be dismissed as provided in c h a p t e r 3 8 .

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(D); Code 1982, § 11-35)


Sec. 24-57. - Fireighters to respond to alarms.

Whenever an alarm of fire shall have been received, the firefighters shall proceed with the fire fighting apparatus to the premises on fire and remain on duty there so long as necessary to extinguish the fire, or until they are relieved from duty by the chief of the fire department.

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(E); Code 1982, § 11-36)


Sec. 24-58. - Training and education program.

All regular firefighters are encouraged to participate in a training and education program in accordance with the following provisions:

 
(1)



(2)


(3)


(4)


(5)



(6)



(7)
 
Upon the approval of the chief of the fire department of the school to be attended and the course or curriculum to be studied, the cost of tuition and books shall be paid for any regular firefighter enrolling for such instruction which leads to an associate degree in fire protection, unless otherwise waived by the council.
Upon satisfactory completion of 11 semester hours of instruction in approved courses of fire protection or related courses at any accredited junior college, college or university by any regular firefighter, that firefighter shall receive a proficiency remuneration of $15.00 per month.
Upon satisfactory completion of 22 semester hours of instruction in approved courses of fire protection or related courses at any accredited junior college, college, or university by any regular firefighter, that firefighter shall receive a proficiency remuneration of $30.00 per month.
Upon satisfactory completion of 32 semester hours of instruction in approved courses of fire protection or related courses at any accredited junior college, college, or university by any regular firefighter, that firefighter shall receive a proficiency remuneration of $45.00 per month.
Upon satisfactory completion of courses resulting in an associate degree in fire protection from any accredited junior college, college, or university by a regular firefighter, that firefighter shall receive a proficiency remuneration of $100.00 per month; provided that firefighter shall have been continuously employed by the city as a firefighter for more than 42 months.
The chief of the fire department shall keep and maintain a record of the participation and achievement of all firefighters in the program pursuant to which the above proficiency remunerations are awarded, and this record shall be available to the civil service commission and the city council for use in valuating promotions.
Unless otherwise waived by the city council, any firefighter that voluntarily leaves the service of the city after having had paid for him, by the city, the cost of such education and training as provided in subsection (1) of this section, authorizes the city to deduct from any monies due such firefighter a sum to reimburse the city for such training and education according to the following schedule:
 

a.	Within one year from the beginning date of such education and training, 100 percent of the total cost of tuition and books paid by the city

b.	Within two years from the beginning date of such education and training, 80 percent of the total cost of tuition and books paid by the city for that firefighter.
c.	Within three years from the beginning date of such education and training, 60 percent of the total cost of tuition and books paid by the city for that firefighter.
d.	Within four years from the beginning date of such education and training, 40 percent of the total cost of tuition and books paid by the city for that firefighter.
e.	Within five years from the beginning date of such education and training, 20 percent of the total cost of tuition and books paid by the city for that firefighter.
 
(8)
 
The approval of any educational program under this section for any regular firefighter is conditioned upon the consent and approval by that firefighter to the reimbursement schedule above, which shall be acknowledged by his enrollment in any such program.
 

(Code 1972, § 203A.01(H); Code 1982, § 11-37; Ord. No. 3777, § 1, 8-12-1974; Ord. No. 4677, § 1, 2-28-1995)


Sec. 24-59. - Interference with duties of ireighters.

No person shall in any manner hinder, obstruct or otherwise interfere with any firefighter or other employee of the fire department in the discharge of his official duties.

(Code 1982, § 11-38; Ord. No. 3913, § 1, 11-14-1977)


Sec. 24-60. - Police to assist in enforcement of article.

The police department shall help in the enforcement of the provisions of this article. (Code 1972, § 203A.01(G); Code 1982, § 11-39)

Sec. 24-61. - Mutual aid and emergency aid.

Under the authority set forth in RSMo 70.873, and in addition to any mutual aid powers under other provisions of the city Charter or this Code, the city police, fire and public works departments are hereby authorized to respond and provide assistance as requested in any mutual aid or emergency aid request in the state or in any bordering state. Any officer or employee of any such city department providing assistance pursuant to this provision shall have the same powers, immunities and liabilities as if acting within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city and shall be considered on active duty as he would be when acting within the boundaries of the city. Any officer or employee of another jurisdiction providing such mutual aid or emergency assistance to the city shall have the same powers, immunities and liabilities as if acting within his own jurisdiction.

(Code 1982, § 28-6; Ord. No. 4574, § 1, 1-12-1993)


Secs. 24-62—24-80. - Reserved.


ARTICLE IV. - MUTUAL FIRE ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT



Sec. 24-81. - Contracts with neighboring municipalities, districts and the state.

 
(a)










(b)
 
The city hereby contracts with the cities of Berkeley, Brentwood, Clayton, Crestwood, Des Peres, Ferguson, Frontenac, Glendale, Hazelwood, Jennings, Kirkwood, Ladue, Olivette, Richmond Heights, Rock Hill, Shrewsbury, St. Charles, St. Louis, University City, and Webster Groves; and the fire protection districts of Affton, Antonia, Black Jack, Cedar Hill, Chesterfield, Community, Cottleville, Creve Coeur, Fenton, Florissant Valley, High Ridge, Lemay, Maryland Heights, Mehlville, Metro-West, Mid County, Moline, Normandy, O'Fallon, Pacific, Pattonville-Bridgeton, Riverview, Robertson, Rock Community, Shady Valley, Spanish Lake, Springdale, St. Charles County, St. Peters, Valley Park, West County EMS and Fire, West Overland and the State of Missouri. And upon the passage and approval of a like ordinance by legislative body of any such cities, districts, or the state, the contract set out in this article shall become effective between the city and such cities' districts or the state for interchange of services of their fire departments upon the conditions and provisions herein set forth.
The city manager is authorized to approve and sign renewal contracts as may be received from time to time from any city and district referred to in subsection (a) of this section.
 
(Code 1972, § 302A.03(A); Code 1982, § 11-66; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974; Ord. No. 4298, § 1, 5-12-1987; Ord. No. 4793, § 1, 8-12-1997; Ord. No. 5120, § I, 9-9-
2003)


Sec. 24-82. - Duty to respond to ire alarms.
 

The fire department of the city shall respond to alarms on call in any part of the cities and districts referred to in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 ; and the fire departments of such cities and districts shall respond to alarms on call in any part of the city, except as otherwise provided in this article.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(B); Code 1982, § 11-67; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974; Ord. No. 4298, § 2, 5-12-1987)


Sec. 24-83. - Termination of agreement.

Any of the contracting cities referred to in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 may terminate the contract set out in this article as to such city at any time by the passage of an ordinance to that effect and giving written notice thereof to all other cities who are parties to such contract. Such termination shall take effect 60 days from the date of service of such written notice.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(C); Code 1982, § 11-68; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974)


Sec. 24-84. - Certain departments to serve certain cities.

It is understood and agreed that the fire departments of the cities of Crestwood, Glendale, Kirkwood and Olivette, and the Manchester Fire Protection District, respectively, serve as and shall be considered to be the fire departments for the cities of Oakland, Warson Woods, Meacham Park, Elmwood Park and Town and Country for all purposes of the agreement set out in this article.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(D); Code 1982, § 11-69; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974; Ord. No. 4298, § 3, 5-12-1987)


Sec. 24-85. - Consideration for service.

The consideration for the service of the fire departments of each municipality mentioned in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 shall be the service given for the protection of the lives and property in such municipality by the service of the fire departments of the other cities hereto, and no compensation shall accrue or be paid by any of such cities for the service of the fire department of any other of such cities.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(E); Code 1982, § 11-70; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974)


Sec. 24-86. - Liability of participants.

None of the municipalities referred to in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 shall be liable to any other of the municipalities for failure to respond to any call by the other of such municipalities, or for delay or negligence or mistake in receiving or responding to any call, nor shall this contract be interpreted as being an agreement for the benefit of any third person.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(F); Code 1982, § 11-71; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974)


Sec. 24-87. - Liability to employees.

None of the municipalities referred to in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 shall be liable by reason of the contract set out in this article to any firefighter, official or employee of the other, nor shall any firefighter, official or employee of any of such municipalities be considered for any purpose a firefighter, official or employee of any municipality other than the one by which he is regularly employed.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(G); Code 1982, § 11-72; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-74)


Sec. 24-88. - Damage to equipment or property to be borne by owner.

In case of loss or damage to the equipment or property of the municipalities referred to in s e c t i o n 2 4 - 8 1 while responding to fire alarms, such loss or damage shall be borne by the city owning such equipment or property.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(H); Code 1982, § 11-73; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974)


Sec. 24-89. - Telephone lines between stations.

In effectuating the purpose of the contract set out in this article, the parties hereto may maintain direct telephone lines between the fire stations of each of them to be used exclusively for fire calls. In such event, the expense of such lines shall be shared equally by the parties hereto.

(Code 1972, § 302A.03(I); Code 1982, § 11-74; Ord. No. 3769, § 1, 4-22-1974)

Chapter 28 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION



Sec. 28-1. - Purpose.

It is hereby declared as a matter of public policy that the protection and enhancement of buildings, structures or land improvements of special historic, aesthetic or architectural significance are required in the interest of promoting the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the city. The purpose of this chapter is to:
 

(1)


(2)

(3)

(4)

(5)

(6)
 

Protect, enhance and perpetuate such buildings, structures or land improvements and districts which represent or reflect elements of the city's cultural, social, economic, political and architectural history;
Safeguard the city's historic, aesthetic and cultural heritage as reflected in such buildings, structure or land improvements and district; Foster civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the past;
Strengthen the economy of the city;

Promote the use of historic districts and landmarks as educational and cultural resources of the city; and Promote the safety and general welfare of the residents of the city.
 

(Code 1982, § 15.5-1; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)


Sec. 28-2. - Deinitions.

The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Alteration means any act or process other than demolition that results in changes to one or more exterior features of a building, structure, or object in an historic district or landmark site.

Demolition means any act or process that destroys or removes, in whole or in part, any building or structure in the city. (Code 1982, § 15.5-2; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)

Sec. 28-3. - Establishment of historic and preservation commission.

 
(a)

(b)
 
Creation. There is hereby created an historic and preservation commission (hereinafter referred to as the "commission").

Members. The commission shall be composed of five members. All members shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. All members shall serve three-year terms, unless appointed to an unexpired term, except that the initial appointees to the commission may be
 

staggered and appointed to terms of less than three years. (Code 1982, § 15.5-3; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)

Sec. 28-4. - Designation of historic districts and landmarks.

 
(a)







(b)
 
Recommendations. The commission shall recommend to the city council the adoption of ordinances designating single structures or sites, portions of structures, groups of structures, landscape elements, works of art, or integrated combinations thereof having a special historical or architectural interest or value as landmarks or historic districts. Such recommendations shall be accompanied by written reports describing the character and significance of the proposed landmark or historic district, outlining its proposed boundaries, and recommending appropriate guidelines to preserve its significance. Recommendations should also consider any master plan, zoning requirements, projected public improvements and existing and proposed renewal and development plans applicable to the area to be affected by designation.
Designation.
 

(1)
 

Standards for designation. A structure or site, portion of a structure, group of structures, landscape element, work of art or integrated combination thereof may be designated for preservation if it:
 
a.	Has significant character, interest or value as part of the development, heritage, or cultural characteristics of the city, state, or nation by reason of age or by reason of association with important figures or events;
b.	Exemplifies the cultural, political, economic, social, or historic heritage of the community;

c.	Portrays the environment in an era of history characterized by a distinct architectural style;

d.	Embodies those distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type or engineering specimen;

e.	Is the work of a designer whose individual work has significantly influenced the development of the community;

f.	Contains elements of a design, detail, materials or craftsmanship which represent a significant innovation;

g.	By being part of or related to a square, park or other distinctive area, should be developed or preserved according to a plan based on a historic, cultural or architectural motif; or
h.	Owing to its unique location or singular physical characteristic, represents an established and familiar visual feature of the neighborhood, community or city.
 
(2)



(3)


(4)

(5)



(6)



(7)
 
Notification of property owners of proposed designation. Notice of a proposed designation shall be hand delivered or sent by first class mail to the owners, as listed in the property tax records of the county, of property proposed for landmark or historic district designation. The notice shall briefly describe the proposed designation and state the time and place of the public hearing.
Public hearing. The commission shall conduct a public hearing on each proposed designation of a landmark or historic district in order to obtain the viewpoints of affected property owners, residents, and other interested parties.
Commission recommendation. The commission shall make a recommendation with respect to the proposed designation to the city council.

City council approval. Upon receipt of the recommendations of the commission, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the application. Following the public hearing, the council may approve or disapprove the commission's recommendations, which shall not be binding on the council. The council shall cause notice of the time and place of its public hearing to be published.
Notification of designation. After approval by the city council of the ordinance designating property as a landmark or historic district, the council shall send to the owner, as listed in the property tax records of the county, of each property so designated or each property within the designated district, by hand delivery or first class mail, a copy of the ordinance.
Support of listing of properties on the national register. The commission may support the nomination to the National Register of Historic Places of local historic landmarks and districts that the commission judges have contributed to the history, architecture, and culture of the city.
 
(Code 1982, § 15.5-4; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)


Sec. 28-5. - Certiicate of appropriateness applications for alteration.

 
(a)


(b)


(c)



(d)
 
Approval of alterations in historic districts or involving landmarks. A certificate of appropriateness for alteration in an historic district or involving an historic landmark must be applied for and approved by the commission before any alteration is made.
Standards for alteration. The Secretary of Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings, 36 CFR 67, shall be the commission's general guide concerning landmarks and buildings in historic districts.
Submission of plans to commission. An applicant for a certificate of appropriateness must submit proposed plans to the commission in sufficient detail for the commission to have full knowledge of the requested alteration, particularly as to how the proposed actions will affect the appearance, materials and architectural design of the landmark, or the buildings, structure or land within a historic district.
Public hearings on applications for certificate of appropriateness. The commission shall consider applications for certificates of appropriateness at meetings of the commission. Each applicant for a certificate of appropriateness shall be notified of the commission meeting at which his application will be considered at the time that the applicant files his application. At the commission hearing at which his application is considered,
 

an applicant shall have the opportunity to make a statement and shall have the opportunity to examine any witnesses who may testify at the hearing. In addition, the applicant shall have the opportunity to discuss the application with the members of the commission.
 
(e)



(f)


(g)
 
Acceptable commission reactions. The commission may approve, deny, or approve in amended form the proposed plans subject to the acceptance of the amendment by the applicant. If an applicant chooses not to accept a proposed amendment, the application is considered denied.
Report on determination. A written report of action taken or determination by the commission shall be forwarded to the applicant. The report shall state reasons why an application is denied or amended.
Conformance to certificate of appropriateness. All work performed pursuant to a certificate of appropriateness shall conform to the requirements of such certificate. In the event work is performed not in accordance with such certificate, the director of public works or his designated representative shall issue a stop work order and all work shall cease. No person, firm or corporation shall undertake any work on such project as long as such stop work order shall continue in effect.
 
(Code 1982, § 15.5-5; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)


Sec. 28-6. - Certiicate of appropriateness applications for demolition.

 
(a)



(b)


(c)
 
Approval of demolition of any structure in the city. A certificate of appropriateness for demolition for any building or structure in the city, except single-story residential garages and residential storage sheds of less than 300 square feet of floor area, must be applied for pursuant to this section, prior to any demolition occurring.
Review standards. The commission shall review every application for a certificate of appropriateness for demolition and shall recommend approval or disapproval to the director of public works.
Standards for demolition. The commission shall determine whether to recommend approval or disapproval for a certificate of appropriateness for demolition by considering:
 
(1)

(2)
 
The criteria listed in  s e c t i o n  2 8 - 4 (b)(1)a—h; and

The state of deterioration or disrepair or structural unsoundness of the building or structure, the practicability of rehabilitation, and whether the property can be rehabilitated or restored with a reasonable economic return to the owner.
 
(d)
 
Procedure for approval or disapproval. After receiving a recommendation to approve or disapprove the application for a certificate of appropriateness for demolition, the director of public works shall then approve or disapprove the application. In making this decision, the same standards that guided the commission in subsections (c)(1) and (2) of this section shall guide the director of public works.
 
(Code 1982, § 15.5-6; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 5108, § I, 5-27-2003)


Sec. 28-7. - Public safety exclusion.

This Code shall not be construed to prevent the demolition of any structure or any elements of such structure when the authorized municipal law officers certify that it is necessary to demolish the structure in the interests of public safety.

(Code 1982, § 15.5-7; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)


Sec. 28-8. - Appeal provision.

Any person aggrieved by any decision pursuant to this Code may, within 30 days thereafter, apply to the city council for review of the decision. Written requests for review of said decision shall be filed with the city manager. The city council may, after a public hearing, reverse, modify, or affirm any decision pursuant to this code using the same respective standards of consideration stated in this Code.

(Code 1982, § 15.5-8; Ord. No. 4978, § I, 2-27-2001)


Chapter 30 - HUMAN RELATIONS


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
